column8: ...so make sure to search the whole area else you may miss something. The gardens aren’t really that impressive but the buildings really are: ornate carvings, secluded courtyards and secret views.

We entered Patan Museum , through its Sun Dhoka , a finely engraved and gilded gateway constructed in 1734 , facing one of the most beautiful squares in the world and renovated by His Majesty's Government of Nepal and the Austrian Government , at 1015 on 5th November , 2018 . The Sun Dhoka was topped by a beautiful , golden pediment . At the apex of the pediment was a huge Kirtimukha holding his two long fangs with his two hands coming out through his majestic mane . Below the Kirtimukh was the family of Lord Panchmukhi Shiv with his console Parvati and sons Ganesh and Skand . This family was flanked by Makar torana , ( floral-reptile motifs )with two celestial makars depicted as one third terrestrial animal ( trunk of elephant ) in the frontal part , one third aquatic animal ( crocodile ) in the middle part , one third bird ( tail of peacock ) in the hind portion with extended floral tail .  There was a golden window above the Dhoka ( gate ) , once used by the king to make public appearances .The window enshrined Avlokiteshwara aka Karunamaya ( now known all over the world as Machchhendranath , a famous Hindu yogi ) surrounded by the pantheon of Hindu gods .  The old museum building was reinforced with concealed RCC beams & slabs and retrofitted with moisture resistant membranes to protect the walls and roof from dampness .  We first witnessed Shilapatras inscripted from 659 Ad to 1896 AD . Then we climbed new stair case in the eastern wing .  There we saw a ritual oil lamp with bronze donor figure made at Bhaktapur in 1870 AD and placed under terracotta nitche and torana .  Then we saw five Buddhist beautiful figurines showcased together :  The left hand side bottom most figure was of Chamunda / Kali / Mahalaxmi . It was made of Brass in 18th - 19th century in Nepal . Depicted as a skeletal crone as no other Goddess was , the fierce Mahalaxmi - also called Chamunda / Kali - could not be mistaken for any other female deity .  The left hand side top most figure was of Indra . It was made of Gilt copper in 17th - 18th century in Nepal . Indra , an ancient Hindu God reverred by all Nepalese was recognised by his horizontal third eye , in contrast to the vertical third eye of other deities . The right hand side bottom most figure was of Vajradaka . It was made of Bronze in 17th - 18th century in Nepal . The upturned face with gaping mouth identified Vajradaka , an earth spirit who devours ill influences . Tibetans sometime took medicine through his mouth .  The right hand side top most figure was of Yam . It was made of Bronze in 17th - 18th century in Nepal . Yam , a fierce Buddhist protector , " King of Religious Law " , and the personification of death was unmistakable because of his bull head and mount , the water buffalo , a combination shared with no other deity .  At the centre was White Tara of the Seven Eyes . This idol was made of Cold gold , Copper alloy , Gilt , Paint and Semi precius stones in 18th - 19th century in Tibet . This form of the Buddhist Goddess Tara was reognised by her five extra eyes , one on the forehead andtwo each on the palms and soles .  The tantric images of Buddhism , the deities are in sexual embrace . We appreciated two such images :  One such image of Yam and His Consort .This idol is made of Cold gold , Copper alloy , Gilt , Paint and Semi precious stones in 15th century in Tibet . Yam , " Lord of Death " and " King of the Law " united with his consort in the vigorous pose of the fierce deities . Both wear skull studded crowns , his was a garland of severed human heads ; hers was a girdle of humane bone . They were supported by Yam's mount the water buffalo . Originally a Hindu deity , Yam was eventually incorporated into the Buddhist pantheon as a protector .  Another image was of Chakrasamvara and Vajravarahi . This idol was made of Bronze and Gilt in 18th - 19th century in Nepal . When the esoteric Bodhisattva Chakrasamvara united with his consort Vajravarahi , the " Dimand Sow " , they represented the union of wisdom and compassion that is the actuality of enlightenment . This extreme multiheaded and multiaremed representation was characteristic of Tantric imagery .  We also learnt the Lost Wax casting process depicted detail by various photographs having commentary .  The visit to the museum is a MUST to know the cultural richness of Nepalese civilization .  Entry Fee : Included in Patan Darbar Square Entry Fee Timings : 10:30 to 16:30 Closed : Tuesdays
Make sure to visit the 2 entrances of main museum with golden doors, and the unmarked entry through a tall arch. See arch in photo. You’ll want half day to explore.

The Patan Museum has a good collection of art and artifacts housed in a marvelous building. Patan is not as busy as Kathmandu so it is a good place to appreciate Nepalese architecture and style. It was also, very fortunate, to escape the massive damage of the earthquake of 2015 and while there was damage it was not as bad as Kathmandu. Spend time reading the explanations of art and explore the museum. Nowhere else in Nepal you will find such information readily available. Guides don’t know much about these treasures and will probably give you the wrong information. The entrance to the museum is included in the ticket for the entire complex.

column7: Nearing the end of our visit to Nepal - perfect
column8: The ancient city of Patan is known in modern terminology as the 'City of Fine Arts'. Well, my husband and I thought this might be a bit lite. The main square is filled with Hindu temples and Buddhist monuments. The Royal Palace pretty much dominates the area in its granduer; the 16th C stone Krishna Mandira with 21 pinnacles dedicated the Lord Krishna does hold its own. But there's more: the Golden Temple and the terra cotta temple of Mahabouddha. By this time we were pretty much exhausted after three weeks of none stop travel. We gazed at all the above maybe more in a stupor than wonder. Now, by reviewing this extraordinary city, we fully appreciate what was to be our last great adventure in Nepal. Nameste.
seeing how the kingdom of history progressed through Patan is fascinating and this is a great visit- make sure to stop at the shop

Patan museum and the area surrounding is where I grew up and everytime I go back to Nepal, I make sure to visit the Patan museum area. Each time I go I fall in love. Right around the corner is an extremely typical newari restaurant ,"Hona cha", that always seem to fascinate me. The only complain I have is that the Nepalese government should not charge tourist Rs 1000 while Nepalese people are only charged Rs 10. Tourism is vital to Nepal and the tourists are helping the economy. That rate is outrageous and if I were to be a tourist, I would not visit Patan Museum even though I fall in love each time.

There is so much to see around the Kathmandu Valley but if you want to see a place with a long history of arts and culture then Patan is the place to go. It is about 40 minutes from central Kathmandu and there is an entrance fee to the main area. Patan is in Lalitpur district which is said to have been founded in the third century BC by the Kirat dynasty and later expanded by Licchavis in the 6th century. It was expanded further by the Mallas during the medieval period. Patan Durbar Square is listed by UNESCO as one of seven Monument Zones that make up the Kathmandu Valley World Heritage Site. Some Patan monuments were badly damaged in the 2015 earthquakes and work is continuing on rebuilding. But the Museum is outstanding and well worth a visit with excellent displays giving the history of Nepal. There are magnificent displays and the signage is in both English and Nepali. Lalitpur has the highest number of renowned artists and finest craftsmen ever recorded in the history of Nepali art. You can only marvel at the intricate wood and metal work as you move through the museum and admire the workmanship of the craftspeople. After visiting the Museum make sure you walk down the road to the Golden Temple - it was spared by the quakes. You can easily spend half a day at Patan and there are many cafes for lunch or tea. Well worth a visit and the entrance fee.
Interesting place to visit. Not very big but it's part of the Durbar Square. It reminds me of some scenes from Dr. Strange... Entrance fees also apply...

Lots of beautiful art and things that I did not know much about. Our guide let us to browse around on our own. Sometimes, you don't have to know everything about what you are seeing. I can just enjoy the beauty of a lovely work or I look at something and think what it reminds me of or I think of the person creating it, what were they thinking about it's future? Do Check this out.

column7: Important part of your Patan visit, don't miss it!
column8: The museum is situated right at Patan Durbar square, in a former royal palace complex. The building was largely spared by the 2015 earthquake, and its beautiful facade gives you an idea of "what was", and perhaps of "what will be" once all the renovations around are completed.  To enter the museum, you will walk through a maze of finely decorated courtyards. The museum itself is compact and well planned, with Hindu and Buddhist artefacts displayed in separate galleries. If you don't feel like an expert in local traditions and beliefs, then this is the right place to start. Most objects are fine metalwork depictions of deities, and insights into the metalwork craft - for which Patan was once famous. Photos can be taken inside.  If you decide to finish your tour at the museum, there is a nice cafe at the back courtyard where you can have a drink and relax. Entry to the museum is now covered by the Patan Tourist Entrance Pass, which you can purchase at Patan Durbar square.

column7: good place for ppl interested in mythology
column8: The museum offers different statues and relic of Tibetan, hindu and nepalnese buddism. It is good that you can see and compare the difference of interpretation to buddism.  For those with western background may have less knowledge on the difference between different schools of explanation. Worthy to go.

column7: Uncover the symbolic meanings of hands, eyes, and feet.
column8: “The eyes, hands, and feet all have symbolic meanings.” This multi-story museum is a focal point to start learning about the meanings behind the statues positions and gestures. You could literally spend hours reading the detailed (in English) information. Near the entrance was a special exhibit of paintings sponsored by “End Sexual Violence.” The students will explain the artwork and you are invited to purchase some hand-made cards.

Most of the museum was spared from the earthquake. It is housed in a wonderful palace. Just seeing the palace, this architectural wonder with its many rooms and balconies make this worthwhile. The exhibitions are fascinating, they give you a good overview of the history of Buddhism. The exhibitions are well lit and signed in English. In the last courtyard there is a small coffee shop where you can get something to eat or drink

A place to be and see  First of all dont forget to take a ticket outside the museum at the beggining of durbare square  We learn a lot about all the statues we see and who they are why are they in this or that position ... We also learn about how the make the statues We learn about hindouisme and bouddhisme  (Dont go to eat at the museum restaurant ...bad experience ...)

This museum is a world class museum that describes and shows the Newar culture of Nepal better than the Metropolitan Museum in New York of Cleveland Museum of art. This is the place to go if you want to begin to understand the history and life of the people of the Kathmandu Valley. You will also see the best description of the lost wax method of casting. Make this an early stop on your tour of Patan and enjoy lunch at the Museum Cafe

column7: A bargain and an amazing place
column8: I love museums and I've been in a lot abroad where the exhibits are fascinating but hard to interpret as info isn't in English. At Patan Museum all of the information is in English and is very detailed. The museum focuses on the history of Hinduism and Buddhism in Patan and has lots of interesting statues. There is two parts to the museum both included in the ticket price of 400 rupees. While the main museum through the golden door is intact the second half through a neighbouring door off the main square has had some damage from the earthquake but this doesn't seem to have had much in it anyway. Definitely make a visit here.  Tip: I paid 1000 rupees for a guide as I wandered into patan square, and apart from showing me where the golden temple is he wasn't worth the price (though he was a nice person). Definitely don't get a guide for the museum as I saw one person being shown round quickly by the guide and he didn't see much of the exhibits. Do it at your own speed.

We visited the Patan Museum in mid-April, shortly before the quake. We don’t know the current status of the museum, but it’s such an underrated attraction we want to give it a shout-out on Trip Advisor, regardless.  The museum is housed in a wing of an old palace that that has been beautifully restored to create a thoroughly modern museum. The collection, mostly sculpture from the Kathmandu Valley, exceeds anything you can see in the western world.  The glory of the Patan Museum is its display. Not only is each individual object attractively displayed, the entire museum is intelligently organized around the goal of clarifying the numerous deities and religious inspirations that gave rise to Nepalese art. The helpful wall texts and labels are in fluent English.  We saw the Patan Museum in the course of a crowded schedule and didn’t have time to explore properly. A couple of hours would have been better.

column7: This is a must visit if you are a historian / history amazes you.
column8: a place with a great historical significance. Also known as Lalitpur, these were the courts / the royal complex in Nepal. The area has a lot of anciant temples, court rooms, monestries, etc. The most prominant is the Living Goddess Patan Kumari's temple. A seven year old girl living as a goddess in the temple & the stories aroung this religious belief is amazing. it was worthwhile understanding the culture, beliefs, etc of the local residents to familarise yourself with the culture. I was amazed by what I saw & herd.... cannot describe as I believe words are too less..... I'd rather say that you need to have a first hand experiance & you'd agree to what I say - "It is a once in a lifetime experiance".

column7: The Museum Behind the Golden Door
column8: The Museum is housed in an old royal palace of the former Malla kings of the Kathmandu Valley; which has undergone a thorough restoration through the joint efforts of the Government of Nepal and the Austrian Government.  The exhibits are kept in excellent display cases with professional lighting. In my opinion this is definitely one of the best museums in Nepal.  There are panels showing how the metal is worked to make the exquisite metal idols that Patan is famous for.  There is a stiff entry fee (NPR 250 for SAARC nationals). BUT the museum is definitely worth it!!!!  Tip: Please spare a minute to climb up to the Bell Tower. You will get a Panoramic view of the Patan Durbar Square.

It might be all too easy to drift past this location and not realize the treasure it is.  Spread across two of the historic buildings of Patan's Durbar Square, the museum is a definite must-see. The first building houses the exhibition areas and some of the artefacts and figurines in bronze, gilt and gold are stunning. The museum's incorporation into the old building, an ex-palace and monastery, during renovation has been handled with great care and there is little externally to suggest what you will find along the maze of corridors and floors.  The second building has no exhibits as such but is, itself, the exhibit with incredible carvings and features in its stone and woodwork. To the rear, there is a sunken pool within a garden that is being renovated.  The museum café is very smart and reasonably-priced. There are two museum shops. The items on sale are good quality and their prices reflect that. Don't expect bargain hunting here.  Signs in English, located near the items on exhibition, provide good explanations about the history, etc. of each.

column7: Well organised, A view into Nepal's history
column8: A visit to the Patan museum gives a peek into Nepal's rich history. The various sculpture are neatly organised. Make sure you dont give this a miss.  In case you hire a guide, you can visit this museum at the end of his guided tour.

Without doubt Nepal's best museum. A lot of hard work has gone to this gem to gather all the exhibits and make them tell Nepal's cultural and historical story. The stunning collection of artworks is simply amazing. And the way the exhibits are presented makes it very easy for the visitor to get a sense of the achievements people of Patan were capable of attaining. A new wing has also opened. It's prized exhibit is the gold fountain head, stolen some years ago and now recovered. The original piece is part of the museum collection; the one you see in the sunken royal bathing fountain pool is an exact replica. A large piece of land at the back is also being converted into a garden, which should add to its attraction. A fee is charged to enter the museum.

column7: Visit to Patan Durbar Square Museum
column8: This museum has a very complete collection of Nepali art from the last two centuries, besides modern art, which gives the visitor a chance to compare the different art cultures changes. Besides they have special rooms for temporary exhibits. Should be visited by all art lovers.

The Patan Museum is truly a gem! Duck through the door in the middle of Dhurbar Square in Patan and enter into the museum courtyard. A second courtyard door takes you into the garden area and to the entrance stairs leading up to the exhibits. The place is exquisite, and done in typical Newari style.  Here, laid out in a very manageable format, is an incredible lesson in Buddhist and Hindu iconography, shown through a carefully chosen and exhibited selection of bronzes. One can either just enjoy a superficial view of some of the best bronzes or really learn about the attributes and symbolism of the different gods and goddesses that people the country of Nepal. Descriptions of the figures and pictured are clear and concise. The museum is relatively small, so the visitor is not overwhelmed by too many things to see.  Below in the courtyard the garden outside is a small restaurant, with tables tastefully placed under trees, near flowers or under a covered roof area. Food is fine - not overly gourmet - but an okay combination of Nepali (geared to non-spicy tastes) and western fare. Service is friendly, but can be slow, so be prepared. It helps to have a reservation during the busy lunch hours.

Those who are visiting the Darbar Square can take about an hour and hop in to the this place. The museum is rich in cultural history and background of the evolutio of the Patan people in Nepal. The museum also portrays the significant contributions of ancient Patan people in the History of modern Nepal. Those who are interested in History and Anthropoly will find this museum nice. To me, it was just another local history museum. There are good food stalls outside of the museum. Do not miss the meaty offerings. They are mouth watering.
A gem in Patan. The museum is very informative with outstanding displays. Well laid out modern museum.

You should really try some momo, spring rolls or coffee here. But it will also be the dessert that will make you come back again and again: both the chocolate mousse, the orange bomb and apple pie are great!

column7: Great introduction to buddhist and hindu art and religion
column8: A great introduction to buddhist and hindu art and religion. Very nicely laid out and very informative. Note that you need to pay an entry fee to Durbar square and a separate entry fee to the museum. If you're planning on multiple trips to the square, or are in a nearby hotel and will be coming through on multiple days, then make sure you get the ticket issuers to give you an extended pass - it doesn't cost any extra

The place is indeed a living museum. It is a nice blend of Hinduism and Buddhism. The temples surrounding the museum area are mesmerizing. A must visit if you are in Kathmandu - find time for Patan. Could have been 5 stars if it was a little bit cleaner.

column7: If you visit one thing in Nepal - go to Patan Museum
column8: The Museum that was conceptualized and curated by a team of international experts is definitely the best place to learn something about the art history of the Kathmandu valley. One of the most extraordinary collections of bronze figures is on display with very well done descriptions of the techniques used to create them. If you visit anything in Nepal - visit the Patan Museum!  There is a nice garden behind the museum where you can relax from the noise of the city, probably the most peaceful place anywhere in Patan. The coffee shop is beautiful but overpriced and the food is boring. Bring your own packed lunch and sit in the small garden or have a - also expensive but very good - lunch at Cafe Swotha only a few meters below Durbar Square!

Located in a restored Royal Palace the museum is a gem. The exhibits are beautifully displayed, the interpretation materials brief and informative, supported by poster sized deeper descriptions that are worth the few minutes to read the well written text. The palace is peaceful, the lighting subtle, the exhibits subtly presented. One of the highlights is being able to sit on red window seats on the third floor, looking out on the Square through dark, carved window frames. There the air is cool and one can watch the world go buy and imagine, for a while, what it must have been like to live there.

The Hindu imagery that assails you wherever you travel in Nepal is eye-opening but rather confusing for the uninformed. Thankfully the Patan Museum can help. The museum is set in an evocative old building with views down into the Durbar Square, and the exhibits are presented in a modern and informative style. It tells you a lot about the main gods and their various attributes and iconography.  All in all, it was a very relaxing and useful break from the hustle and bustle of the streets of Kathmandu.
We can find peaceful environment there. It is the best place to hangout with friends. Sound of bells make you feel so relaxed.

you pay nep 1000 which helps the repair work to the temples. you will be bombarded with offers from guides to do a tour with them. if you choose to do only go with registered guides. and negotiate the price depending on how long you want and how many people. we wondered around ourselves . after 5pm you dont pay entrance.but very crowded with locals who just socialise and sit around on the steps of the temples.

Went here with my guide and she explained everything about old and new. The square has many stories, not just the earthquake in 2015! Highly recommend a visit. I read people complaining about the 1000N$ (€3.50, U$3) and wonder why such complaints are written, considering you'll pay more for a rubbish coffee at Starbucks! Pay the same amount, go in and make sure you visit the Patan palace museum, beautiful and calm cafe inside for a relaxing drink. Enjoy!

we went to the Nepal last April 2019 for Everest base camp trek and I had a 2 day extra so we went to see the historical patan durbar square which is located in the center of Lalitpur district. A traditional Newari city patan has a unique traditions as well as identity. As we were with my tour guide we were lucky to know most of the things that patan durbar square has. The Main durbar square is so unique with its wooden architecture as you see there so much wood work everywhere. The main house used to be the living place of the Malla Kings family in the past and there are many courtyard and Chowk inside. All of this Chowk has it’s own significance. Siddhi Narsingh Malla was the king who built many temples and part of durbar in 17th Century B.C. Krishna Temple was the another attraction over that squre which is built by the stone only in sikhara style which took 25 years to build by King Siddhi Narsingh Malla. The place also popular for buddhisim as there are a lot of sakya family and it has a lot of Boudha Bihar. Hiranya Barna Mahavihar is one of the popular. Overall our experience to patan was great with my guide Sabin as I learned many things. I tried the Newari food which was awesome but quite spicy. You must visit patan if you are coming to Nepal. Highly Recommended.

The 600 year old royal palace is open 24 hours. The pagoda like beautiful structures with intricate wood carving are lighted up at night.  People of all ages flock the square, and for the natives, drinking tea there is a trend.  One can spot tea vendors, balloon sellers and souvenir stalls in the courtyards. It also has excellent roof top restaurants.  The complex has beautiful museums. The worn out bricks tell the story of how long they lay there, while the complex as a whole depict the grandeur of royal lifestyle in ancient times.

The place was built during 11th Century. Lovely place with beautiful architectural construction. Lots of beautiful photo opportunities. It can get very crowded so make sure to take pix before starting a narrative tour.

column7: The most charming Durbar Square of Kathmandu valley!
column8: Patan(Lalitpur) is right across the holy river of Bagmati from Kathmandu city. In the heart of old town we have a magnificent palace and 9 different temples.Collectively it is known as Patan Durbar Square.It reflects the skill and craftsmanship of the Malla period(1200 to 1768 A.D.). The natives,known as Newars have carved exquisite wooden windows and amazing stone temples and statues all around. The Keshav Narayan chowk(courtyard) has a museum that was set up by Smithsonian Institute.It is now partially damaged by 2015 earthquake but renovation is going on at full speed and everything should be ready in about a year. The inner garden has a delightful cafe as well. This part of the palace was renivated by the Austrian government(1983-1997). The Mul chowk(Central courtyard) and the private bath/ritual courtyard were done by US,UK,Nepalese and Japanese help. The Mul chowk has statues of the Ganges and Yamuna river with some fine wooden struts (with original colors) dating back to 17th century. The private bath complex is the oldest part of the palace dating back to 1610 A.D.It now has a gallery open with some frescoes.The inner garden area is a currently a workshop for woodcarvers (for renovation purpose) and it also has a lily pool with some stone figures. The main golden door leading to Keshav narayan chowk is flanked by two wooden benches where seniors sit and talk about nostalgia. Next to it is a water spout dating back to 570 A.D. and has two small resthouses. Bang infront of the golden gate is the stone temple of Krishna,the 1st Shikara style temple of the valley. The shiva temple next to it has some extraordinary wooden struts. The surrounding area has some restos and a small flea market and some souvenir shops. Just a minute away from Bhimsen temple in a back alley is Om handicraft which is fixed price and has some quality products. Overall the Patan Durbar Square is a wonderful area to visit.

I was on a solo trip to Nepal earlier this year in January. Basically I wanted to explore and run some rivers on my Kayak. But during my visit there, I was told to visit this place by a friend. Just how wonderful Patan Durbar square is for a traveller to experience some of the tradition & heritage structures of Nepal. the oldest of the three cities in the Kathmandu valley. The square is made up of 136 courtyards and 55 temples. It was destroyed by earthquake few years back and some places are still under maintenance & rebuilding stage. However all the structures are amazing, heritage Hindu kingdom. There are a number of historic temples & they include some extraordinary erotic carvings on one of the temples in a traditional South Asian style. The Patan Museum is also simply amazing. Also the Mahabuddha temple is an easy walk from here. You might get lucky to witness some religious processions and performances in the square as well. Supposedly these are fairly regular. So if you want to time your visit accordingly may be you can contact the tourist office before visiting. As I was alone and also less crowd during the morning visit, I got absorbed and felt so spiritual. There is so much ancient culture in this thriving and beautiful place.  This is a must visit place for all travellers to Nepal. I ticked off another beautiful destination on my unknown places bucket list :)  I bow down to this land and the people of this land who have built & preserved this gem of a place for the world to experience.

It is not cheap to visit this area. I cannot see how they can police whether someone has paid or not but it is good to know that your money is maintaining this amazing place. There are 3 main styles of architecture, all fantastic in their own way. There is a museum in the Royal Palace. You could spend hours wandering around Patan Durbar Square and its surrounds. Make sure you wear comfortable walking shoes and have the energy to spend time in this area.

column7: A Tacky Old Gate Without Much Class
column8: This is not the best part of Patan or a very classy exit or entrance but it is there and allows you in and out. At some stage it make have looked spectacular but not so much now.
It's just something that you might pass on your way. There is certainly no reason to make any effort to see it. It's not ancient or anything.

column7: One of the Three Durbars of Kathmandu
column8: The Pathan Durbar Square houses the Palace of Pathan. It was built in the 17th Century. The palace temple is used to make sacrifices. On either side of the temple door was golden statues of the 2 river goddesses of the rivers that flow there. It is definately worth a visit.

column7: Came for the exercise, kept coming back for everything else!
column8: I arrived alone in Nepal in January of 2019, at a bit of a loss. Found mention of this class on Facebook and popped along. Since then I have been going at least twice a week, if not more. Everything is provided so you can just turn up. There's a mixture of classes so you can find the style that suits you but all the teaches are fantastic. A particular thanks to Kanchan and Joyce though!

Namaste 🙏🏻  We had the great pleasure to meet with Kanchan in Kathmandou and to experience his talent for Yoga & Meditation 🧘‍♂️. On top of being an amazing human filled with kindness and happiness, Kanchan is very knowledgeable on the ancient techniques and is very good in transmitting the message. His track record, hard work and connection to the universe make him a wonderful encounter. We went back home with some good messages that we will put into practice. We HIGHLY recommend him.  Thanks a lot Kanchan, we hope to see you soon!  Driss & Henri.

column7: Good place to be humble and learn
column8: Classes are great with the perfect blend of different yoga styles, even for the beginners. Our teacher Kanchan sir is exceptionally encouraging and comforting. He brings out the strength in everyone. The best thing is everyone feels at peace by the end of class and that is what a yoga class should do. It really is true spiritual practice.

I have done two yoga retreats and regular classes instructed by Kanchan and it has been purely amazing. Kanchan’s way of teaching is flexible, holistic and he has the ability to modify the classes for each participant’s level, from the beginners to the more advanced ones. The classes were gentle but also challenging enough. Kanchan’s holistic life style as a yogi showed up in his multidimensional expertise and deep and healing spirit that he could create into the classroom. Also his thorough knowledge on yoga philosophy brought depth to the experience. I felt like a different person after the 3-days retreat in a monastery - more open and calm, both physically and spiritually.  If you travel to Nepal and are looking for a great yoga experience, I definitively recommend to try Kanchan’s classes!

It has been a great pleasure to get to experience yoga with Kanchan! He is a person who has really special sensitivity to see individuals energy, and modify all classes observing participants bodytypes, level of energy and group dynamics. His strong knowledge about yoga and yogic lifestyle , bright and sensitive personality make classes and retreats more deep, more opening that I have ever experienced before.  Warmly recommend for those who want to practice yoga!

Very experienced, friendly, easy to get along. Being with Kanchan for 2 days make me find easily myself the peacefulness, solace and embracing myself to happiness. The best part is he bring be around with his scooter make me feel as part of Nepali 😀 Thsnks Kachsn for having me. Will be back to see you soon. Namaste!

I was fortunate to meet Kanchan during my visit to Nepal. I have tried many classes in Kathmandu and have found Kanchan's classes to be one of the best. He is an amazing yoga teacher, very talented & passionate, attentive and welcoming. His vast knowledge of yoga and his yogic lifestyle is evident in his teaching style. I have tried both, group classes and private classes, and can recommend his classes to anyone wanting to delve deeper into their practice! I will definitely be back for more classes once back in Nepal.
great choice of yoga classes: Yin, Hatha, Vinyasa, Meditation etc Nice set up. A lot of different teaching style/teachers that can suits everyone. Warmly recommended.

column7: great spot for finding the right yoga class/retreat
column8: I booked a three day yoga course wih the pranamaya Team in the Neydo monastery in the valley of kathmandu. It was a really great experience and I enjoyed the easy communication, the extraordinary people I met there and of course the special and energetic place the retreat was as much as the yoga style which I never heard about before (universal yoga).

column7: Love it: Modern, well-kept studio with friendly and skilled teachers.
column8: I'm a freelancer who lives near Thamel and going to Pranamaya studio for Yoga is part of my daily routine. I usually attend morning classes, but sometimes I go in the evening because I love it so much!  The teachers are all extremely friendly and kind - not difficult to make conversation with any of them. They're also very skilled at what they do and accommodate Yogis of all levels (beginners and advanced students). Each teacher has their own style and flare, and I look forward to the variety and what I'll learn from each class.  The studio is well kept and is cleaned often. They have a bathroom which is always clean and tidy as well. They provide all the props you need for classes (mats included) at no extra charge. They also offer many different types of workshops; anything from healing bowl sessions to self-help seminars to Vinyasa Flow dance parties.  I've been attending for nearly 3 months now and truly feel like I have a family there. It also helps that its right above Himalayan Java which means lots of post-class coffee and opportunities to make new friends and have fellowship.  If you're travelling, stop by for a class! We'd love to have you :)

column7: Good classes but too many last minute cancelations
column8: Out of three Pranamaya yoga instructors I've practiced with, two were really great and led classes that were both relaxing and strengthening. The third instructor was extremely rude and unsupportive of a newcomer to the class who appeared to not have much experience in yoga - this was very surprising and off-putting and I will make sure not to take her classes again. The main issue with the Patan studio (I haven't used their other two locations) is that they cancel classes frequently, and often at the last minute. This month they have canceled eight sessions so far. It's very unprofessional and I don't think I will be renewing my membership.

For yoga lovers, Pranamaya Yoga offers yoga classes at different venues throughout Kathmandu. Their premises are clean with plenty of props which are part of modern yoga experience. The instructors are professionals and helpful; some are better than others. Popular venues become very crowded, like the one in Thamel. The policy seems to be to accommodate everyone inspire of the cramped conditions. I have often ended up with my nose very close to armpits or crotches! The yoga hall in the Thamel centre is long and narrow-ish. The instructor and practitioners are all on the same level. Often, trying to observe what the instructor is doing becomes difficult. I have ended with more than a few cricks in my neck, undoing the benefits of yoga practice. They seem to have raised their prices as well. I hope I can keep up my yoga lessons.

column7: Plenty of space to park the palanquin...
column8: His Nibbs moved to Kathmandu some months ago and has taken quarters in Patan. Yoga is one of his passions, so naturally he sought out the best establishment in town: Pranamaya. "Quiet, plenty of variety, welcoming atmosphere, and plenty of room to park the palanquin" he says. Having accompanied my dear eccentric uncle on numerous occasions, I would agree. Teachers elsewhere have been want to apply too much pressure on the dear chap, and displace his cronky hip. But the teachers here are personable and sensitive to the capabilities of their students. They also stock a good range of kit, and we have decked ourselves out in style.

column7: Good for short or long term stays in Kathmandu
column8: I have lived in Kathmandu for 10 months and have been at Pranamaya Studio Patan several days a week the entire time. The studio offers a variety of yoga styles and different teachers, so there's always a style and a teacher that suits you. I find the quality of teaching to be very high and the atmosphere is super friendly. Whether you're a novice yogi as I was or very experienced, you can be challenged and supported by the great teachers. I've been on one retreat to the beautiful Neydo Monastery, which I can definitely recommend if you want to learn a bit more about Buddhism, meditation, and yoga. I have made good friends there and will miss it very much now that I'm leaving Nepal.

column7: Very good classes offering different yoga styles
column8: I have been visiting Pranamaya Yoga Studio in Patan for 2 months. I find it very nice that the studio offers different kinds of classes with different teachers, so you can choose your own style and pace and get a better understanding of yoga. I gained some very rewarding experience from a number of teachers and a new insight into yoga thanks to my visits.

column7: Excellent yoga studio with lots of yoga events around KTM Valley
column8: If you are interested in doing yoga in Nepal, Pranamaya is definitely the place to go to. They have a wide variation of regular classes in three shalas around KTM. Studios are beautiful, western-style studios with professional touch and excellent teachers. I practice mainly ashtanga myself, and find especially Boudha studios classes (and teachers) excellent.  Pranamaya also organizes regularly different workshops in the studios, and the ones I have attended have been very good value for money. Looking forward to participate in one of their monastery-retreats soon. Pranamaya is a lively and warm community and they really push the level of yoga in Nepal high. Love it!

If you are looking for a good place to start or continue your Yoga experience while in Nepal, go here. I started my Yoga experience with Pranamaya and I've continued practising it now for one and a half years with them - somehow got addicted.  The studio is located in Moksh complex in Lalitpur, very conveniently in between all the restaurants and coffee shops that make Patan so attractive. The studio is very clean and professionally managed. Most techers and students are westerners, which is a little drawback. If you want to get in touch with the Expat community in Nepal - that's probably the best starting point.  They offer drop-in classes by many different teachers which makes it very easy to try out the different styles of yoga. It's no problem for people without experience to join the classes, just come and grab a mat - that's finally what made me tryout yoga. Uncomplicated!

column7: Yoga community in the heart of Kathmandu
column8: Pranamaya is a community of yoga lovers in the heart of Kathmandu Valley. The variety of teachers from many branches of asana practices ensures one can find a style and a teacher that meets what ever one is seeking from yoga practice. As a beginner yogi I did exactly this until I found the style and teachers that suited my needs. I can warmly recommend Chrissie Grogory´s Iyengar classes. With the emphasis on alignment and preciseness I have found them very suitable to learn asanas properly. Combination of Iyengar and Vinyasa Flow with wonderful teacher Lennette Boner has brought my practice to a whole new level. The monthly yoga celebrations and retreats are a chance to further widen the perspective and deepen the knowledge beyond asana practice. And a chance to make new friends!

column7: One of my all-time favorites in town!
column8: I've been a big fan of this joint for years. It's in the top-tier of eateries in Kathmandu, at least in terms of its menu range and prices. The quiet, hustle-free setting, lovely garden and trees just besides the eating tables, are a fresh change from most places in town. Have always enjoyed their food and cocktails, which, for a change, are quite better in terms of mixture and preparation, in comparison to most other bars in town. I've tried almost all their dishes, and I do appreciate the effort the kitchen and restaurant staff make. I'm proud to call Dhokaima one of the few places that I and my wife simply can just drop into whenever we're around Patan.

column7: Please review your staff hiring process, for at least teach them how to behave with customers!!!
column8: So, i and a friend of mine went to this place to have coffee and a smoke. The waiter told us that, there was no electricity hence no coffee. Hearing this my friend ordered two cups of tea. While we sat, just out of courtesy we ordered a plate of momo so that coming to the place might seem reasonable to them. Up on waiting on for more than 25 mins for a plate of momo, my friend, he asked the manager( he was or not) to cancel the order if it were to take any longer. 10 mins later he turns up with a plate of momo, literally dropped it on our table with a thud and this is what that (floor manager or so) had to say with a condescending tone" We dont have our momos frozen, we make it fresh". Upon seeing the hole patched momo that took freakin 35 mins to cook with that attitude with no more than 10-15 customers in the whole restro, I stood up to pucnh that guy in the face, but maintained by cool and told him that he was insolent , an illiterate to behave like that with the customers.  How can this place hire someone with such behavioral traits. Shame on you 'Dhokai ma Cafe' to not have even care to say sorry to us on his behalf, but stayed quiet. Shame On YOU!!!!

Wow really hard to put into words our experience here. As a chef and a person with a knowledge of the food industry I can honestly say that this was one of the worst dining experiences of my life.  I'll try be brief as I know how essay reviews are to read but seriously what I endured deserve one.  Yer well lovely looking place, nice sounding menu on the mid price range with some really tasty sounding options. Great. Lovely courtyard, perfect.  So my partner ordered the lasagna and I the Chinese inspired mushroom and pak choy. We had a great feeling as a place with great reviews and such a well presented location deserves high expectations. The lasagna came out only slightly warm and the middle still cold and as you can see from the photo not a lot of love to gratinate the cheese on top, a basic for any lasagna. We asked for it to me warmed and knowing a microwave would be the answer and sure enough after 2mins we received it warm of course but as expected the microwaved cheese leaking oil!!! Tasty!  My dish was actually very tasty exept for the 3rd bite including a rock. Okay, this for me is seriously unexectable, it is in no way a mistake, it tell me that the kitchen doesn't wash their pak choy!! This can pass for a street food dish but not a restaurant of this standard.  I called the waiter over, he took the dish away and then brought me the menu.... I of course asked for the manager. To be honest she handled the situation fairly well, after I suggested her to offer me a new complementary dish. The BLT that I ordered was tasty but really nothing special. Besides the fact that after the first bite she came running over to ask if "I loved the new dish." Seeing the waiters and the manager in the reflection standing around the cash register and looking over in my direction and laughing didn't help the already broken trust.  Wouldn't return and if I were you don't bother. Stick to a street side samosa.

Attentive service and lovely set up but food was mediocre, far from what was expected by the look of the place. I ordered a lasagna (i felt like a change from dhal bhat!) and it came cold... I asked them to warm it and obviously they didn't use an oven because the cheese was chewy, not crispy at all. I thought it was kind of my fault for ordering a ladagna in Kathmandu... But damn, for those prices they could put a little love and finish the job, because the flavour wasn't bad! The service was good though. I think the kitchen should raise the standards.

Returning to what once was a nice restaurant with good service and good food, we found quite the opposite. It took more than 1 hour to receive our food and then we were even more disappointed! The fish and chips came out with potato chips and not french fries. When we asked about the chips the waiter replied that the kitchen was busy and they didn't have time to make more. The management also said the same thing upon our complaints. The panini also came with potato chips although the waiter assured us that fries came with the sandwich. As our meal ended and we paid the bill there was no compensation for receiving the wrong food. The waiter and management were not willing to consider reducing the price or giving anything complimentary. We felt our time at the restaurant was an imposition to the staff and will not return!
Pizza and pasta are really tasty and good garden style for relax. Prices are a little higher compared with other reatarants near by.

If you feel like setting the dal bhat aside for a night, this is a pretty good option. They have a wide range of mufti-cultural foods, from Italian to American-style, to French to Indian and of course, Nepalese. Surprisingly, they handle this wide range of options pretty well (hard to do). You can also get a delicious sweet here. So far this is the best place to gathering with family I had while in Patan!

I stayed at Sarovar Service Apartment for 1 month during my assignment in Kathmandu. I felt warm and secured all the time. The room is very nice designed, clean, and fully equipped with kitchen materials. I enjoy self cooking very much. The AC (heater), hot water and other electric appliances are well functioned. I don’t have to worry about electricity cut off. The location is surrounded by restaurants, supermarket, food stores, fruit stores and many local stores. I received many advices about where to visit during weekends and holiday as well as very kind assistances when needed with prompt action. I feel like a VIP guest. I like coffee and breakfast in Sarovar’s restaurant very much. It is not only a place for stay but it is like a second home for me :) I would stay here

I don’t know where to start. I really enjoyed my stay here. Bhanu Joshi the head of operations went above and beyond to see that I was comfortable. He even upgraded my room from hotel type room to a 1 bedroom apartment. I felt like a king. Always had hot water with plenty of pressure. Bed was comfortable with a nice duvet to cover myself. Hey, I had 2 a/c -heaters in bedroom and in living room. Heenu and Rebica at front desk always gave me a warm and welcome smile every time I walked by. Plenty of plugs everywhere. I liked all the different types of lighting in each room. Having wall sconces next to my bed makes me feel like I’m home. Plenty of places to eat in walking distance. Today I took a $5 taxi to Thamil to do some more shopping. I’m so glad I’m not staying over there in

Wonderful architecture, enriched with wonderful works of art. Everywhere you look you can experience beautiful works. The monuments in the Durbar Square date back to the medieval Malla period from 16th to 18th century. Also Vishwanath Mandir Temple. The temple is built in Pagoda style and the temple is guarded by two stone elephants. Located near the Bhimsen Temple.

column7: Food was fine, but tried to steal our money when paying on card
column8: Simple meal was fine and reasonably-priced but ruined by appalling dishonest service by one member of staff.  However, upon leaving, we tried to pay our bill of R555, and were told we couldn’t pay on card because the machine didn’t accept MasterCard. (This was a lie as we had been there 2 days previous to this incident and paid on Mastercard.) The woman on reception basically ignored us, answering the phone on two separate occasions when she was apparently serving us. When she eventually did let us try our card, she swiped it and typed in R5,555.55 instead of R555 and pressed enter to put it through. I pressed cancel to no avail, so pulled the cord out of the wall to make sure we weren’t charged and we left without paying.  We did return later and paid for our meal, directly to the manager and made our situation known. It was a real shame as the service from the two young men who had served us at our table was attentive and friendly.

I went here for dessert and I was not impressed. The brownie I ordered was dry and flavorless, kind of like what I used to make when I was a kid playing in the kitchen. Then the ice cream was terribly, you know when it goes all icy and seems to have been refrozen after it once melted? I will say though the venue is nice and peaceful.
Been here couple of times. Multiple times. But the ambience and food is awesomely delicious. Nepalese taste but made is continental style. Bettet with frens and families and date. Best wishes

column7: Average food, ok atmosphere, ok staff
column8: In spite of references in a few travelbooks we did not experience anything special at Cafe de Patan. The tastes of our Newari traditional vegetarian dish (a set menu composed of several snacks in the menu) did not blend, the food did not seem to be prepared with care and presentation does not look in anyway like the photo's presented by management on their site.Not worth visiting again.

column7: Great Cafe in Patan and awesome Staff!
column8: Lovely place to have lunch on a sunny afternoon with a clear view towards some of the old buildings from the outdoor seats. I had chosen a secluded spot to dine in order to have some privacy from the crowd dining at the cafe. I was served by Pawan and he went all out to make sure I was dutifully served by checking in regularly to see if I need anything else to be served (the seat location was well concealed by some landscape features so he needed to make effort to get to me). Awesome service it was! The food was nicely prepared and delicious too. Definitely one of the place to enjoy a good meal and quiet break from the bustling city.

column7: To avoid!! Not the same place then before???
column8: - the place is very beautiful ! In a sunny day it is very plesant :) under a tree. But thats all positive !! just ask to drink and go to eat outside  - we were welcome by a server not so smiley( no probleme every body can get tired) - we asked 2 banana lassi, but they didn't have banana !!! They didnt have banana in septembre in nepal just go 1 min outside your restaurant, there are thousands of banana selling !!!! ( that was not the only thing missing ! ) bytheway plain lassi were good. - we asked for 1 chicken momo for snack and then after for meal, 1 hamburger special patan museum and 1 fried fish  - we didnt get our snack but directly our meal, i told 2 times momo first ...ok no probleme we took our meal ... thinking maybe it takes more time to make momo ?? - then we see other group comming 30min after us asking a chicken momo and getting it quickly ...so i asked why we didnt get our momo he said i will ask in the kitchen and just asked for a new chicken momo (i understand nepali...). He told us it will take timee 15min to warm the water .... "do you still want it?" .... we asked the momo 45 min before and they just dont want to tell us they forgot our command and a "sorry" its thing that happens but just "sorry i forgot " would be ok but nothing ....so we didnt take the momos  - the meal : vegeteble were not so bad but the fish was such small pieces with lots of oil .... and in the other side the hamburger was so dry ++ and untasty i didnt think it was possible my wife forced herself to eat the half ...and with the hamburger the bread didnt look fresh .... and with it 8 small piece of french fries miam miam  - then last we saw a expresso machine we sayed yeah a good coffee ...but its was not possible no electricity .... (so we took a normal pot of cofee and it was good so ok)  And for all this 2 lassi and 2 meal and a pot of cofee 2667 rouppies ...  We were really dissapointed ......

column7: Oasis of calm to reflect and imbibe!
column8: Second time I have been here and it is a welcome respite from the busy streets of Durbar Square in Pathan and a place to have good food and drink whilst contemplating your recent visit to the Golden Temple and other fine buildings and temples nearby!  We had the buffet with a soup to start and crème caramel dessert plus tea and a beer all very well priced and very tasty...thoroughly recommend you visit here when exploring Pathan!

The museum was shut for the day, but a group of us had dinner after local cultural entertainment by a dancing group. Dancing really interesting. So buffet style meal which was fine. They had passed around some nibbles ... The best being the spicy cubed potatoes. The courtyard setting, with tables and some covered area is an oasis in durbar square.

We came across this cafe by chance while my husband and I were taking a walk in the Durbar Sqaure. Their service is simply brilliant and the food was awesome. As I prefer spicy food, I made a request to them to make my dish extra spicy and that is exactly what I got. The food was so enjoyable!  This is situated in Durbar Square. However, it is quite quiet and you can get the meal and the rest that you so need by that time of the day after walking through the ancient cities. This is undoubtedly one of the best cafes that I visited in Nepal!

Visited this cafe at the beginning of April. Looked like a pleasant spot to have a drink and some cake but our experience was ruined by the rudest waiter that I have ever encountered.Was ignored for twenty minutes after arriving. Admittedly he was busy with a group but 20 mins is a long time to wait. When he finally came over I asked for a menu only for him to shout "beer, yes, no??" and walk away without bringing a menu. Another waitress (who was much friendlier) eventually brought us a menu. When we went to pay the waiter, there was no thank you. This cafe is clearly meant to be upmarket but the shockingly bad service we got clearly doesn't reflect this.....

column7: Beautiful and quiet place in the middle of Durbar Square
column8: Well, I was surprised to see the picture of Museum Cafe here on TA because it seems there were many people enjoying the place. When we went there, there were only a couple of us so I loved that it seemed so peaceful and quiet compared to the noise at the Durbar Square. The cafe is inside the Royal Palace and it is very interesting to find a modern garden setting in the middle of everything that's of Newari architecture.  The cafe is operated by the Summit Hotel so the service is expectedly very "hotelish" -- white napkins, well-dressed waiters, etc. It's not a complaint though but I've always liked to dine in places where it's more local and authentic. Nevertheless, the cafe is a very welcome break from all the walking around temples and red-brick houses. I loved that it was quiet and peaceful and of course, service was very prompt and very attentive.  There was very good food presentation, expectedly again! But I wouldn't say it's extraordinary. But it's not bad. :) We ordered Nepali food so just by that alone is already a big thing for us. Naturally, it's a bit pricey compared to the other ones. But if you're looking for a relaxing lunch hour, then maybe you should choose this one.
This is a pleasant place to have a meal after shopping and sightseeing. It is quiet with plenty of space. The waiter was excellent, and they do make a wonderful apple cake.

We were really looking forward to returning to Cafe Swotha after our stay in Traditional Homes Swotha back in 2013 when we pretty much had most of our meals here. We were delighted to see that the dining room is still intimate and modern, with...More

column7: Impeccably decent and clean eatery just off of the mayhem
column8: Our expedition around the UNESCO region of Patan was chaotic and total bombarded our senses ... we were exhausted from batting off beggars and Con-artists seeing us walking through and seeing dollar signs. We turned a corner and found this little place twinkling in white fairy lights. The familiarity of the fairy lights enticed me in. I was on guard Incase it was another lure under false pretences, but I was pleasantly surprised. Kind hospitable waiters attentively serving each table and making every one of the guests feel welcomed and appreciated. Their level of English was impeccable and their class of service. The restaurant had traditional music piping through at optimum level. Table spacing was decent too with the bustle of the restaurant thriving the atmosphere yet, impossible to over hear conversations as they haven’t greedily packed out the venue. Fresh carnations upon every table, with clean table cloths laid neatly and considerately. The place is a dream and totally transformed our day! The food was beautifully presented and well portioned. Prices are more than fair and printed on the menu (so no need for the tiresome bartering!) come here when you come to Patan. It will make your entire trip feel more calm and beautiful. It will also make you realise that not all Nepalese are out to make money off of you without giving back! Really. The most memorable dining experience of Patan.

column7: Great place to eat in a relaxed environment
column8: Nice food and Nice waiters. Great little western style restaurant for those wanting to escape Kathmandu for a few hours. Had the gnocchi and the veg pita. Both were high quality and quantity. (almost) Nothing Nepali about this place, which is nice after a week of Nepali food and restaurants (which we also like).

column7: Nice modern restaurant next to Swotha Hotel
column8: The place is clean, recently decorated with very good menu, both western and Nepalese. The service is also excellent. It is one of the few place sin teh area which opens around 7am: most others open only at 9am..

Beautiful interior with modern design, excellent service, and great location right next to Patan Durbar square. We had the Gnocci and Veg burger. Gnocci are actually schupfnudeln, but tasty. The veg burger was not my favourite. Didn't try the Nepali Thali, but in my opinion is quite overpriced.  Overall, ok food and a bit overpriced.
Clean and modern interior. Attentive service. Small menu. Good food - although portions a little small for the price. Chocolate mousse was delicious.

Roasted pumpkin salad was a novelty. The ambience was just a added merit to the tasty food. Pork chop and pasta swotha were appetizing. The sounds of birds on background would make your visit worth. A visit to patan durbar square would be incomplete without eating at cafe swotha.. Go, visit and taste the best.

column7: Cozy and Modern Ambience, Fabulous Food
column8: We were taken right away by the very cozy and modern ambience. Spent Christmas and New Years Eve in Patan and Cafe Swotha became our holiday home away from home. It's upscale for the area, so a little pricier than some, but fair and really worth it. Everything we tried was outstanding- esp the quiche, soup of the day- pumpkin garlic, and spinach, veggie pita, tart with salad. I think it's only seasonal, but DEFINITELY get a warm glass of mulled wine. My boyfriend is from Germany and it got the legit-Glühwein seal of approval. The staff are the sweetest. Thank you for some lovely meals, Swotha!
Had a pleasant dinner with my wife. The food is really nice. Highly recommended. The cafe itself is a renovated old style Newari house, which gives you an authentic Experience

Just one block of the northern end of Durbar Square near Swotha Square you will find this gem of a cafe / restaurant. Great food, pleasant staff and nice modern atmosphere. A nice alternative to what is on offer around this upcoming area of Patan. Not that well signposted but is at the end of a short lane on your right as you pass the souvenir shops. The "Melting Pot' craft shop is on the corner of the lane. Definitely worth a visit!

I ate here on two separate occasions and was happy with both. The breakfast stood out in particular and was my favorite western style breakfast I had during my stay in Nepal.  I also ate lunch here and was happy with that meal as well. I would skip the house wine that they sell by the glass though as it is lacking.

column7: A hidden gem just outside Patan Durbar Square
column8: I have been in Kathmandu Valley for 2 months and I have been hard-pressed to find restaurants with a diverse menu, ambiance, and service that make me want to go back again ...and again. I found what I was looking for at Nina's cafe in Maharajgunj, and ironically, Nina herself recommended I check out Cafe Swotha in Patan. Cafe Swotha is indeed a special place. I had the BlackBoard Christmas special consisting of pumpkin soup, garden salad, grilled chicken with a mushroom sauce, carrotts, green beans, mashed potatoes, and an apple crisp ... an absolutely divine meal for the fixed price of 1099 Rupees ($11 US). The attentive staff and the ambiance matched the quality of the food. I will surely be going back!

column7: Perfect for a late Afternoon Coffee and Snack......
column8: We were looking for somewhere for a late afternoon coffee and snack and happened upon this place by chance. Very clean, modern and hidden away down a back alleyway so it doesn't interfere with the locality. We had a Hot Lemon with Honey / Coffee...More

I spent two weeks in Patan and this restaurant and its sister, Cibo Bistro, became my two favorite places to eat. I was lulled back over and over by the soups: potato and carrot, zucchini and carrot, cream of tomato…all served with a slice of brown bread that was some of the best brown bread I had in the entire country. Plus it was the first café I came to trust with fresh salad, i.e. organic greens, sundried tomatoes, black and green olives, and a light dressing. Nearly every day if not every other day, I came in and sat at what I deemed “the Chef’s table”, i.e. one of the barstools in the front entry way. The guys that work there are so sweet and if you’re traveling alone, strike up a conversation. These guys (3 of which are in their early 20s) are pretty outstanding in making your wishes come true. One day I wanted a mulled wine (hot wine) and boom – they served one up though it wasn’t on the menu. Another day I really was craving avocado and shazam…an avocado salad with olive oil, lemon juice, salt and pepper. It’s a shame that their online presence isn’t more prevalent for the foreigners who search the internet for recommendations because I’d go here any day of the week, (probably every day of the week) if this was a restaurant near my home. And I can guarantee you that if they ever come out with a cook book for soups, I’m the first one to buy in. They put places like Panera, Pret, Eat, etc to shame. Oh and by the way, I had the ham and cheese sandwich twice (yum – real cheese!), the spaghetti Bolognese (fantastic meat sauce), the pepper steak (ok this was alright – not my favorite piece of beef in Nepal – that was in Pokhara, but still good), and they make the best crispy French fries I had locally. And if it helps two big tips: 1. They are open every day 7am-10pm and 2. It’s a bit harder to find as it seems no one ever knows places that are even within a block of them…it’s very close to Café Pagoda in Durbar Sq, Coffee, Tea and Me, and Newa Chen B&B. Sometimes people know Swotha kiosk, but I found that every time I asked about Swotha Sq, not a single local knew what I was talking about. Guys – thanks for making me feel at home, always having a seat available for me, and keeping me company.

This restaurant lives up to the expectations after staying in the B&B Traditional Homes Swotha, to which the restaurant belongs. Dishes cooked to perfection, well balanced tastes and served by knowledgeable and friendly staff. They make you feel welcome and at home. Best on the menu: Nepali Thali, their lassies, cheesecake and rich and creamy chocolate mousse.

column7: We Kept Coming Back to This Place
column8: A more contemporary and modern approach to the usual cafes found in the area. Coffee was served with plunger and they tasted decent. Desserts were jolly good. Pastas were also beyond average. During the four days in Patan we visited this place three times.
Breakfasts were excellent blend of nepali and continental. Thali was honestly one of the best i've ever had.

The Swotha Cafe downstairs from the Traditional homes is where (wait for it), where I had the best food I ate in 3 weeks in Nepal - and I ate some lovely food in Luxury mountain lodges and other hotels. This cafe is the closest you'll get to a french pavement cafe in Nepal, I should think, and when you just want a change from the generally wonderful spicy food, with a simple but delicious pancake or omlette or the amazing chicken skewers then you've found your place. This is THE place to eat in Patan as far as I'm concerned,and I tried a few, as I'm a bit of a foody. I'd enjoyed it so much, I intend to drive from Thamel for a leisurely lunch and to see the Durbar Square (which is in my opinion the best of the 'big 3' Squares) next time I'm in Nepal. Highly Recommended!

column7: Beautiful , Clean , Fascinating and Impressive Golden Temple
column8: We entered Hiranya Varna Mahavihar /.Kwa Bahal / Golden Temple , just at a 5 minutes walkable distance from Traditional Homes SWOTHA where we stayed and from Patan Darbar Square after paying Rs 100 as an entrance fee at 0515 on 15th Nov 2018 . There was a sign board guiding the tourists to enter Hiranya Varna Mahavihar aka Golden Temple guarded by two huge , life size stone lions ( one male another female ) . The temple got this name because of the gold plated pagoda type roof , beautiful golden facade and other golden edifices that adorn the mahavihar . We went there so early to listen to the listened to the sounds of chanting of prayers , revolving prayer wheels , ringing bells , etc .We sat there experiencing divine vibrations for an hour . We took a break of 3 hours and returned at 0945 .  A guide accompanied us around the temple explaining the history and significance of the temple and many figurines , statues and paintings adorning the walls of the temple ,  This three-storey golden pagoda of Shakyamuni Buddha was built in the twelfth century by King Bhaskar Varman .At the entrance , we were confronted by two large brass elephants with riders , as the guardians .The brass and silver doorway was topped by a gorgeous repousse bass relief of the Buddha sitting in the Bhumisparsha mudra flanked by his two disciples , Sariputra and Mudgalayana . Afterwards there was a shrine adorned with a silver and golden chaitya .Behind it , there was a main shrine of Buddha .  Inside the shrine there was the bejewelled Buddha having an elaborate crown on his head . A huge Prabhamandal was intricately carved in gold on his entire body . Outside the shrine a beautifully carved panel showed various life scenes of the Buddha .  The design of the complex represents all the three main vehicles or Yanas of Buddhism . The main shrine represents the basic exoteric Shravakayana , the large Tibetan style image of Amoghapasha Lokeshwara on the first floor is the main Mahayanic deity . On the first floor , the principle Vajrayanic deity of the Kwa Bahah - Yogambara with three faces , black , white and red , and three eyes (each) was locked in a passionate embrace with his consort , Jnana Dakini . His first two hands held a vajra and bell . The remaining right hands caressed the breast of the consort and held an arrow. The left hands held a skullcup and a bowl . A jewel , crescent moon and vishvavajra adorn the black hair as an ornament , with a garland of five skulls and the five Buddhas as a crown , having the six mudras , wearing a tiger skin . Seated in the sattvasana , in the lap was the mother Jnana Dakini , white , with one face and two hands . The right hand held a katvanga staff and the left a skullcup - embracing the father adorned with the five mudras .  The Kwa Bahah is the repository of yet another famous text , the gold lettered Ashtasahasrika Prajnaparampita - a key Mahayan text written in India in first century AD .  Though one can not take photographs inside the shrine , she can spend hours together doccumating the various fascinating figurines and paintings along the walls .
This is an amazing temple made of gold! Different then any I saw while on my visit even the architectural style was not typical of Nepal. It’s a must see if you are in the area.

A visit to this place really worth. Full of ancient architecture and statues makes you feel like you are in different era. Very carefully crafted statues looks like they are living. I really enjoyed visiting this place and Patan town itself.

Small but mighty little jem. We stumbled upon this place by accident. What a joy! If you get there this month, the head priest is only 9 yr.s old! He ran into us playing tag with his friends in the temple! He also has a little pet turtle that walks around the interior of the temple. I can't make this up. It's true. Go go go!

We stayed in the hotel nearby Golden Temple. In the morning, we went to this temple to see how Nepali pray. It is a very nice place and a must-visit to see about traditional people and their belief.  You can also light up candles, make wishes and follow each steps how to pray in the temple.  It is not allowed to wear leather shoes inside, so please respect the place.  Foreigners should pay small entrance fee, but in early morning there was no staff to collect the fee. However, we can put some money in donation box.  I highly recommend this place if you book a hotel near Patan Durbar Square.

The temple is much bigger from the inside than it seems from the outside, especially given that one enters it through a narrow-ish lane. The tiers make for great viewing from an architectural perspective. The artwork, like everywhere else in Nepal's temples, is intricate and very detailed. It does not take a long time to visit this temple, and since it's not long way from the main Durbar Square, it's worth taking a look at.

Golden Temple is one of the Amazing craftmen ship's of lalitpur(Patan ) city. Plenty of work around the temple is beautifuly done at that time when this temple was build. This temple is dedicated to Buddha. It's 10 min north west walk from Patan Durbar square. The main care taker of this temple is small boy who perform all his duties to temple. Legend says when patan city was invaded by Muslims long before and no one else can stop them from, one of the brave boy ran into temple for the help, the statue of Buddha spoke to boy saying that just open the box kept inside temple that will help itself. After the boy opened the box, millions bees came out of box to drive enemies. From that day the boy became the main care taker. Even today every morning you will notice a small boy is busy working. Entry fee for tourist.

column7: Absolutely my favorite place in Patan
column8: It is not as badly hit by the earthquake, luckily. It is an absolutely amazing place to enter. Very powerful, very sacred, already from the gate. It was absolutely crowded when we visited since it was one of the biggest holidays that happen once every 4 years only but despite this, it was amazing to be there, feel the atmosphere and watch the people. If you happen to be there on a crowded day too, make sure to go upstairs, sit on one of the small side pavements and just observe the crowd. It is amazingly peaceful watching all these people that visit the temple for peace, health and happiness. I am sure these places are what actually keeps the world together still, despite all the destruction going on around :) Personal opinion, but in all cases, make sure to go if you're in Patan :)

column7: Part of any visit to Patan
column8: You'll visit Patan anyway, so make a little time to seek out and visit this small but very nice temple. It won't take long and is a must-see.
This temple is wedged between modern buildings and has quite intriguing fixtures and features. The details were beautiful
Among many best places to visit in patan this is another. just few minutes away from palace square, this 12th century made golden color pagoda style Buddhist temple is worth to visit.

If you make to the Patan or Lalitpur area of Kathamandu, be sure to visit the Golden Temple. It's very active and many people came to pray at the Buddha statues. It's a very detailed temple and a great fusion of Buddhist and Hindu religions. Enjoy the many carvings out of stone and metal and don't forget to look up on the way in or out to see the Dharmadhatu Mandala.

Well, I have to say there's not much to see in Patan aside from Durbar Square and this temple. It's a Tibetan Buddhist temple covered in gold color. The best thing about this temple I have to say, is the craftsmanship (someone also said this somewhere in among the comments). Whenever I see wood-carving works here in Nepal, I do very much appreciate the effort and time that the craft man put in to create such details. This is a fine example for such excellent work. Obviously, when you're already in Patan, you shouldn't skip this temple.

I had heard a lot about this temple. I was excited as I was told the statue in the temple resembled to real Gautam Buddha. A holy manuscript is read everyday which had special power. And many other things which made my expectations sky high for the place. As I visited the area, the road construction was a night mare. There were no guided alternate roads so we had to literally walk muddy narrow passage. The temple area was small and clean. Well maintained. But I couldn't find depth in anything. So much I wanted to learn but not by reading or listening but by experiencing. I felt, everything I read and told were just passed as tales and nothing more. It was early morning and I could see devotees - male and females flocking the temple. Is it a good idea to throw rice grains and metal coins on century old monuments? For me, the place is overrated. It was wise of old kings to build such mater piece but could not see enough effort to at least showcase it properly today.

column7: Great mo mos and a varied atmosphere
column8: We enjoy this restaurant. They have their own style of mo mo - they are open on the top. The sauce with them is delicious and unique. We have had egg rolls, chicken cordon blue, fried rice, spring rolls, mutton, fish and chips. Other than the fish we have enjoyed the flavor of everything.  Seating can be outside at tables and chairs. Inside upstairs sitting on cushions at a low table, downstairs at regular tables or a semi open area with couches and tables.  Service is good and each persons dishes come out quite close together.

Hugo and I had the most brilliant cooking class at El Mediterraneo. We loved learning how to make Nepalese food, and Bibhushan was such a great teacher. We would recommend this restaurant to anyone, thank you so much for a wonderful day.

Had a great lunch here, yummy paella and friendly service. The manager seems to make an effort to chat with every table which is nice. The dessert is outstanding, we ordered the flan and cheesecake and was gifted the brownie and lemon mousse, enjoyed them all!

Visited El Mediterráneo for the first time and I am in love with this place. I loved the food and the ambience. The owner and the waiter, both are very friendly. They made us feel like we were having luxurious food at home. Even the...More
One of the best meals we have out had in Kathmandu. Nice wait staff, good food, real attempt to make this a more "Spanish" experience.

column7: great food, fair prices, bad (house) wine
column8: clean neat non-pretentious restaurant on the "restaurant mile "in Pata, Given the good rating in tripadvisor I expecte high prices for drinks etc but no, one of cheapes for beer and lime sodo of the better restaurant. I just had a mixed paella, for good food you have to wait, but definitely worth it. Deserts are limited, so see that you arrive in time or make a reservation... got a try from Tiramisou, - excellent. Beer war reasonably priced however unfortunately also here the (red) wine wasn't worth it. A general problem in Patan at least. Stay with other drinks.

You rarely find a restaurant in Kathmandu where they serve good a Tapas menu. In fact, it is almost impossible to enjoy authentic Spanish food in K-town. El Mediterraneo has not only surpassed my expectations as a restaurant with very high standards for food quality--serving fresh sea food with exquisitely beautiful use of spices and herbs, but also maintaining its customer service by training their employees in a graceful manner. Each one of your servers will thoroughly explain the menu to you and provide you with great house suggestions. A great restaurant, which is family friendly. You can go here for a quick bite or go along with your date and leave with an awe because the food is simply too delicious.

The atmosphere at El Mediterrano is excellent. My wife and I stopped in for lunch one afternoon, and the staff immediately welcomed us. We ordered tapas, a Spanish dish in which small portions come out one after the other. Each dish was delightful, and we enjoyed the leisurely style that allowed us to linger and enjoy the experience. The staff went above and beyond to make us happy, even bringing a extra dessert to sample and offering suggestions of places to visit.
