The person didn't communicate very well when i asked what to do. Apparently you order the coffee and pick it up yourself, paying later but there are no prices...you pay what you think its worth. However any sweet snacks have to be paid up front. This is all good when someone explains it, otherwise you are left feeling awkward.  Not exactly my style but I will return quite simply for the great tasting coffee.

Love this place and their unusual and interesting idea - pay what you like for coffee. Went there a few times and each time the coffee tasted different. They do the pour over style and it is hard to make it strong enough for me, but their heart is in the right place so I don't care. Kind of bare bones and tiny place. Be nice it they served food. Not easy to find, on the third floor far in from the street, but everything is hard to find in Nepal.
Great food. Friendly staff and nice surroundings great service from Bibek make sure you have a healthy appetite - I had the nachos and pizza - very filling
Had there pizza carbonara. Thin crust cooked in a stone oven and very tasty. Good place for a good salad too.

column7: Disappointing, low quality of food and service.
column8: We visited Roadhouse cafe, Pulchowk twice in a span of 10 days. Have been going to this place for the last 15 years. However, their signature pizzas are now half cooked, may be because the orders are rushed. They put no seasoning ( the pizzas are flavourless) on the pizzas, every other bite you have use your imagination to use the mix of oregano, tabasco, chili flakes, olive oil to make every bite worth the pain of visiting and waiting for a good meal that you pay to feel good. The food after 20-25 mins of normal wait comes at a lukewarm temperature. Is it because most ingredients are precooked and reheated? Take your guess. What about the crust? Is it celebratory chef tradition to give the dough half baked? It’s not about the warm lights, and eco construction and the disillusioned management. It’s about the food. Its disappointing. Wood fired pizzas are/were not uncommon but roadhouse pizzas stood out because of their consistency and good value. Now it’s on a decline. If the food doesn’t make sense, the charades don’t matter. Moksha has better pizzas than roadhouse, but they are not that great too. Please don’t order their starters, potato skin and their nachos might give you jitters about that late night indigestion and chest burn and if the pizzas could save your visit, you are in for a disappointment, again. Please don’t make a mistake of ordering from Foodmandu either, making a simple grilled cheese sandwich at home is more worthwhile.

Good food, and nice choices. The service is OK, but most of the guys waiting at tables try to be so fast writing and recapping orders that they sometimes make mistakes! The ambience is OK, but the main restaurant can be a bit dark and dinghy. However the food is really good.

Above average, but the pizza was not as tasty as I had been led to believe.A friend recommended this base pizza. Smart interior with modern chique interior, but I wish the food was to match the decor. Was popular with other patrons at lunch-time. Seems to draw a western, english speaking clientele. 5 of us, bill was Rs4791. Yes it was a thin base pizza, but not particularly tasty. I am afraid i have tasted better pizza, in nearby area.

What makes a restaurant a good restaurant? Service? Food? Ambiance? If so, I would like to take the one star away from roadhouse pulchowk. I'm not sure why people would spend thousands of Rs. on such a horrible service. The servers seemed lost and not a single server had a smile or enthusiasm to serve and make it a wonderful experience for the guest. The food was average and the ambience was average as well. Every time I pass through roadhouse and see people either waiting to eat or coming out from the restaurant, I feel sad for them.

Love the food. I've been here a few times. It's a decent sized restaurant with good food and a pleasant atmosphere. Hated the service. Came with a party of 8 and told to go somewhere else. Really? Called today to try and make a reservation...More

Roadhouse is quite famous for its Italian cuisine, and mostly i like to eat the pizza whenever i visit.  Its little expensive than other adjoining restaurants on the same street, however there is no compromise on service and food they provide. Good place to visit but make sure your pocket is full.

This is always my go-to place for comfort food in Nepal. While Roadhouse is most popular for it's wood-fired Pizza, there are a lot of other items on the menu that make this place worth going to over and over. Two of my all-time favorites...More

Eating at Roadhouse is for when you don't really feel like finding/walking to something a bit better. There are several of these around Kathmandu - I've been to the Jawalakhel and Thamel ones, and they definitely cater to tourists/westerners who just want a safe bet.  Prices are high for the quality. Service is not particularly good. Food is OK, but nothing very special. Not really a big fan and wouldn't choose to go back by myself.
Really good Italian style pizza, very nice and pleasant patio that is good relief from the dust of Thamel
Roadhouse make a decent, but not spectacular pizza. Service is a bit slow, but atmosphere is pleasant. Worth a visit!More

Food is nice but only pizza. They don't know what is the service. They put the extra service charge 13% but it is waste.  Me and my friends asked water almost 5 times but they didn't give and say sorry. Maybe they don't know how to say sorry or excuse me.  If you want to make your dinner terrible, please visit here.

Among the restaurants we visited along Jhamasikhel road, Roadhouse café became a favorite. Nice, relaxed atmosphere, interior in very good shape and style (including toilets). Choice of drinks and food was of good variation, and both times we came, our meals tasted great. We sat inside, and I didn't notice if they had a garden where you could sit.

Nice authentic Italian restaurant with a beautiful balcony spot. Good food but the portions are a bit less compared to the cost. More expensive than the standard Nepali restaurants but somehow feels worth it. I would recommend this place but make sure it's a special...More

Excellent authentic Italian food...good ambience...disciplined staff..the portion is a bit disappointing compared to the cost...But definitely worthy Italian cuisine...recommend polio arrosto..serve good bread with extra virgin olive oil n balsamic vinegar....must try this place but make sure your wallet is as fat as u r...More

With great ambience, this little eatery is a real find in Nepal. Plenty of wines and interesting Italian style meats and cheeses are on offer and understandably this restaurant seems popular with the ex pats.

column7: Cosy Italian Trattoria style ambience at its best!
column8: Piano B is the place to go in Kathmandu for genuine Italian food wine, coffee and homemade ice cream! Small place with a typical Italian ambience and family style friendly services. The menu is limited and changes daily but has always classics like homemade pasta, pizza or roast lamb, prepared with great care and fresh ingredients. Very attentive and friendly staff add to the experience and the world class top of the line homemade chocolate ice cream rounds it up as a no miss out Kathmandu experience! Open all days from lunch until 10pm except Sundays when it’s closed!
The restaurant has an interesting and delicious menu and the B&B is great value for money with nicely decorated rooms that make you feel at home.
When friends come this is the first place we check. They have modern rooms, AC and an amazing breakfast. They are close to Patan Durbar. The staff is really awesome too.

column7: Best Restaurant in Nepal - Hands Down
column8: Where to begin?  I arrived on a Sunday evening (I was staying at the Piano B&B above the restaurant). I walked in and instantly knew this was somewhere I could trust. I told the owner, Antonio that I was too tired to think and to just choose what he thought I should eat. There are very few restaurants I would be happy to have choose the food for me, Piano B is one of them. The food is absolutely delicious! I mean every single thing they make is delicious, from the fresh bread, olive oil and balsamic to nibble on while you order, to the cheese and meat plater to the perfectly al dente pasta dishes to the high quality wine they store.  Antonio has established an amazing little restaurant and to anyone in Kathmandu who has heard of Piano B but never visited, you really need to go there. This guy is working his butt off to deliver quality and having spent 7 weeks in Kathmandu this summer, I have seen the time and effort he is putting into his place.  Having stayed at the B&B above I had the pleasure of eating many many times at this restaurant, its hard to find food this good in my current city of Boston, never mind Kathmandu. And if you're reading this thinking, "Italian food? In Nepal? Why?" then you've the same thought my colleagues had when they travelled to Nepal for 4 days last week towards the end of my trip. After I took them there, one commented in the morning that he dreamt of the Spinach Ravioli and despite the two thinking I was crazy to take them to an Italian on their four day visit to Nepal, they insisted we go back the very next night, and were again served with the same amazing food.  Like the B&B the restaurant is well managed, the staff are polite and professional, the ambience is tasteful as is the music. They stock real beer, real wine, real COFFEE, and trust me all of it meets the highest of standards of a classy Italian restaurant. I would say this is the best restaurant in all of Kathmandu and probably Nepal, yes its not traditional Nepali food, but quality is quality!  So just go there! And get the little onion dish starter thing. Oh and the chocolate lava cake. And an espresso to finish. And drink their house white.  I'm coming back!

Reviews of this restaurant have been glowing, but as a former professional restaurant reviewer and wine writer, I have learnt not to take them verboten. It was good to walk into this buzzy little place on a Friday night and the food was indeed good but the big disappointment is that for a wine bar/restaurant with a reputedly serious attitude to wine, the wait staff have no basic training in understanding wine. When I enquired what grape variety an unfamiliar wine on the list was, I was told it was "dry." When I repeated my enquiry about which grape it had been made from, I was told "No grapes - dry." What a shame in an otherwise commendable place. Disappointing also was the lack of contact from the (presumably) owner manager. I tried two or three times to make eye contact to exchange pleasantries with no success. After reading the reviews, I had assumed (bad idea) that he would understand the importance of relationship-building and hosting in the hospitality industry. The ambience was very pleasant and there is an excellent list of imported food and wine items which must be a real achievement in Nepal. The Friday night buzz was high but personally too noisy for a mature age quiet enjoyment. An excellent wine bar, but as a passionate wine love, please educate the staff.

column7: The ONLY Italian place in Kathmandu
column8: Piano B is the only restaurant in Kathmandu where you can find real Italian food, and a real Italian atmosphere as well. FRESHLY made pasta is available, and you will tell the difference...The selection of cheeses is making some justice to the incredible variety of Italian cheese (from mozzarella, to taleggio and gorgonzola) and you can find fresh salame, prosciutto, mortadella and more. The oil is of good quality and they make a fresh gelato (ice cream) as well as good tiramisu. The restaurant is run with passion, and the idea is one of reproducing Italian food as much as possible. Here, luckily, you would not find things like "spaghetti bolognese" that ARE NOT ITALIAN and are honestly disgusting, but tagliatelle with rabbit sauce, or freshly made pesto, or spaghetti with bottarga. THIS Is Italian. They are using real olive oil, and also real Italian cocktails, like "spritz" are available. PIano B is highly, higly recommended.

column7: Excellent food in a very Italian ambience
column8: It feels like home away from home, the food is great (the deconstructed tiramisu is such a brilliant idea!) the ambience reminds me of home and the bistrots we love so much in Europe. You can even buy food of the best quality (cheese and cold cut/meat items especially). The service is good too.
The food is good the ambience is warm, nice and cosy service in courteous. All make a good evening dining experience, but found portions small for the price they charge.

Friday night out sharing a bottle of red wine, several antipastis, ham n cheese platter, pastas and dessert. Loved the risotto balls and ham and cheese platter. Chocolate mousse is very thick, a little too sweet but still good. Make sure to rsvp, place is small and fully booked on weekends!

Piano B is a cosy Italian restaurant, and very serious about its pasta. I am not sure if they make their own pasta but it was on par with the pasta I remember from Filomena Ristorante in Washington, DC, where they make all their pasta in-house.  Despite only two vegetarian main courses, every item we ordered was authentic and good to the last bite. The pretty dinnerware, from the water carafe to the coffee cups and delicious chocolate mousse, was an extra treat.  Last, but not the least, the staff are very welcoming, and sweet. Piano B is easily the best restaurant in Lalitpur.

I was house-sitting close by, and rather stumbled upon this gem in Bhani Mandal! Authentic delicious menu, great service, convenient location. And, now they have a guesthouse with very nicely appointed clean rooms and modern bathrooms. A must visit when in the area and worth the taxi ride across town!

Piano B is a delightful Italian restaurant with good food and wine. We stayed in the area for 4 weeks and it was so good it became "our local". We enjoyed several meals as a couple but also to entertain our friends.It is a little up market, and prices reflect this but very good value for money.

Disclaimer: this is not your quaint kitchen from Little Italy, NYC, or the romantic cafe from your holiday in Sicily. But for Kathmandu, it's the closest you'll get.  I've been in several times now, as it's the one dependably good restaurant in my immediate neighborhood. Even beyond my immediate neighborhood, I can't think of any place better. The food is pretty darned authentic, the wine selection is nothing to sneeze at, the service is... well, the service is on par or slightly better than you would expect for this corner of the world.  I suppose it's the little details. For example, if a place is out of a wine that's listed on the menu, the waiter might suggest something similar, rather than shrugging his shoulders and saying, "Finished."  But again, we're not in NYC or Sicily. We are here.  I've been in on my own, I've also arrived unannounced with a clutch of friends. Every time, the wait staff and kitchen make it happen, and despite my OCD complaints (worked in service industry for 10 years, so I notice things), Piano B is solid as they come out here.  Highly recommend.

Coming back to Kathmandu after one year absence to help with the post-earthquake relief efforts, I was invited by colleagues to dine at the PIano B, after several days in the field. The decor of this small and busy place in Patan was as warm as a Parisian bistro, the pasta and the prosciutto had a perfectly Italian taste, as did the accent of the friendly owner. Lovely place, but make sure to book your table, especially on week-ends!

I decided last minute to have a plate of pasta there. Even it was late, the owners accepted to be sitted at the bar. The place is very cozy, the service very good and the pasta fresh.  You would not be disappointed if you are looking for a place to feel like home.

column7: Great Italian Joint with great beer selection in Kathmandu
column8: So, this is an interesting place started by two italian friends who came to Nepal to teach. However, they ran out of money, so decided to open a restaurant serving authentic Italian Food. The owners are always there taking the orders and also cooking. Love their spirit.  And, they have done a great job. All the dishes are very well prepared. I ordered the Zuccini & Beet Soup, the Shrimp Pasta, and the Bruschetta. Everything was yummy and authentic.  To make things better, it had a great selection of beers. A must visit in Nepal.

I tred this place after it was highly recommended. So I invited a few friends and family to join us. Maybe the expectations were way too high, but the food was just okay. Nothing really out of the world as was expected from most of...More

Piano B has great Italian food with nice wines to accompany the meal. It is a little more expensive that most Nepali restaurants but it is definitely worth the extra cost for the periodic meal there. I sampled two wild boar dishes for appetisers and both were great with yummy lasagne for main course. As the inside is relatively small, only space for 20-25, make sure you get there early or book ahead.

We discovered Piano B while searching our hotel in Patan, after a long motorbike ride on the mountains. It was dark in the evening, but we recognised something familiar, this little, cozy and modern italian restaurant. Nice atmosphere and excellent food, just like in Italy, very unusual to find outside Italy, homemade pasta cooked "al dente". A very friendly place and nice host, like an old friend. Very recommended.

This is the place to be for a perfect( handmade!!!) pasta, lasagna. The whines are great and the place itself makes you feel like you are in Italy.  Price quality is good, the menu prices are included the 13% VAT. The owner is italian and knows what he is doing.  Can't wait to visit this place again when I'm back in Nepal

column7: Très bon repas accueil très chaleureux
column8: We were there yesterday night the boss is super nice and explained us the menu which was nice to make a choice and the food was really good. Nice vibe nice music we recommend 100%!

Good zoo ,have lake with activities like boating ,with many coffee shop around . We spend good time even though It's painful to see the animals in cage ,but it's the only chance to see animals are housed within enclosures, cared for, displayed to the public, and in some cases bred Modern zoos also aim to help teach visitors the importance on animal conservation, often through letting visitors witness the animals firsthand. Some critics and the majority of animal rights activists say that zoos, no matter what their intentions are, or how noble they are, are immoral and serve as nothing but to fulfill human leisure at the expense of the animals (which is an opinion that has spread over the years). However, zoo advocates argue that their efforts make a difference in wildlife conservation and education. Many zoos work to improve their animal enclosures and make it fit the animals' needs, although constraints such as size and expense make it difficult to create ideal captive environments for many species. Animals in zoos often exhibit behaviors that are abnormal in their frequency, intensity, or would not normally be part of their behavioural repertoire. These are usually indicative of stress. For example, elephants sometimes perform head-bobbing, bears sometimes pace repeatedly around the limits of their enclosure, wild cats sometimes groom themselves obsessively, and birds pluck out their own feathers. Some critics of zoos claim that the animals are always under physical and mental stress, regardless of the quality of care towards the animals.

This zoo should be called an exotic animal prison instead. There is a clear disregard for animal husbandry and a complete lack of conservation education. I wish I hadnt gone and I employ you not to go. The animals enclosures are pathetically small and covered in feces. There's no attempt to create natural environments for the animals; further thers no attempt to even have clean and proper enclosures. The animals are in poor health and terrible conditions. If you have a geart at all then dont go!!!

Central zoo of kathmandu valley is located 30 min drive from kathmandu Durbar square to Lalitpur. This zoo was establish more than 100yr old is by Rana primeminister. At that time it was one of the best and lovely place to visit for the animals of Nepal. In the courses of time it could not be modified only very little changes are done to accommodate more animals. Instead of more animals in the zoo we found less animals but more people due to the growth of population and there is no place for children to take. People come here to see people instead animals. Unfortunately one of the beautiful historic zoo of Kathamandu turned ugly zoo.

column7: bad condition of animals and enclosures - stealing from foreigners
column8: we went with the intention of showing our 22 month old son the animals he was learning. We made a big mistake, the animals are few, unhealthy and in prisons - my son did not reognise anything. we were also told there was a child friendly environment, again we were shocked as it was some dirty shutes and no grass, food, shade, or anywhere for him to play. most annoying was the fact that I am British and my wife Nepai - my son is Nepali, and for the elephant ride they wanted to make him - 22 months old - pay fives more than Nepali children, he is Nepali! so the fee for Nepalis is good for the bad environment, charging me four times more as a 'foreigner' is annoying but ok, but asking my Nepali son to pay adult white foreign price is insulting and racist as he just - by accident - looks like his father and not his mother - we are not tourists as live here, pay tax, and work - so not only is it a good example of the cruelty animals suffer here, but a good example how people are exploited and everything is about money here

its the only zoo in Nepal, hence the fascination. Good place for both kids and adult. But needs to me more clean and hygienic. Also there is need more more interactive and educative for the kids as it is the only zoo.
Pretty run down and depressing to see the animals in their small cages. This place needs to have a private company take over and make it a proper zoo since Nepal has so many exotic animals.

column7: Worth it for the tiger feeding
column8: I have mixed feelings about this zoo. Some of the animals do look sad - the cages aren't big, and the vegetation is dry and dusty. Some of the animals show obvious signs of stress, such as the bears that walked back and forth. That said, the employees take obvious pride in keeping it free of litter and looking after the animals as best they can. Signs are in both English and Nepali (although the maps showing where the animals are from doesn't always match the English, e.g. maps of Africa although the text says an animal is from the Himalayas).  The highlight for us was the tiger feeding, which (between 11-12am) lets you feed the tigers in person for NRS200/person. It's not for the squeamish (you're feeding them great big bits of raw water buffalo) or scared (they really want the food and make a lot of noise telling you this, and you are very close), but it's amazing! All up we spent 2 hours at the zoo (including time waiting for the tiger feeding and doing this). Opens 10-5 (not 9-5 as says elsewhere).  At the moment (Jan 2016) they are doing some construction work, building new pens and enclosures, but it didn't seem to affect our ability to see any of the animals.

column7: A sad place for animals but they need visitors to be able to improve conditions,
column8: I'm torn in my review of this zoo. Whilst the conditions for the animals are far from ideal the only way things will improve here will require more foreign visitors to visit. I say foreign visitors because locals only pay 50 rupees to visit but foreign visitors pay 500 rupees. There were a few children's groups here on the day we visited and they were having a great time. If you have nothing to compare this zoo to, you would think it to be ok. Being spoilt with living in Sydney and having a wonderful zoo like Taronga within a few kilometres it was sad to compare the conditions the animals at Nepal Central Zoo are kept in. So I am torn in my review, It's a sad zoo but by not going will just make things worse.

Me and my fried visit kathmandu center zoo. Where there are few animals compare to the other other zoo in asia. we did love to visit central zoo of Kathmandu because there are few animals but well managed . We know that nepal is developing so we did not aspects like modern technology as European country. nice to visit and chill out there...........................................................................

With this zoo being the only one in Nepal I had good expectations of it. However, with my GCSE, A-level and Bachelor's degree knowledge in Biology I was saddened to see most of the animal enclosures. I saw turtles in enclosures with no water, a bird with a broken leg, jackalts in a concrete enclosure, and almost none of the enclosures we're suited to the wild habitat of the animal- for example the majority of the bird enclosures were filled with weeds. I witnessed a group of people teasing and aggravating the leopards, with no keepers present throughout our visit to keep and eye on animal health or incidents with visitors. The fishing lake is over-grown with algae, which is known to shade and kill submerged plants, which then decompose and use up the oxygen in the water which the fish and other organisms need. The grounds were well-kept, and there we're a couple of rides and a park for children. Entry price was good value (500 rupees for foreigners) Overall, I think the enclosures require attention for the welfare of the animals, but I was pleased to see an animal hospital and I would probably not go again accept to raise money to improve animal welfare.

column7: A pleseant afternoon if you have realistic expectations
column8: This is not an internationally competitive Zoo and most cities have a wider variety of species and more spacious cages BUT the zoo is actually really well maintained and all the animals appear to be well cared for. This is a decent excursion for kids to see the animals and you are not nearly as far away from the animals as you would be at most western Zoos. There is a nice pond that you can go paddle boating on, which incidentally is the same pond they bathe the resident elephant in, something that kids really seem to enjoy seeing from the boats. Manage your expectations and you will likely be pleasantly surprised.  Tip: across the street from the Zoo there's a nice little local momo place. Cheap and delicious.

column7: Though small, the Nepalese efforts are appreciated, and they've done a good job.
column8: Zoo is quite small by Western standards, and quite dated. But overall, a descent variety of animals, and caters to locals and families well. The elephant ride I was looking forward too, but due to medical issues, it wasn't providing rides. He was roaming with his trainer around the grounds and you could get great close up pictures with him which was nice. Tigers were the highlight, as were the monkeys for me. Two beautiful Bengals, looking very happy and healthy took the attention of most crowds. Though the zoo is dated by modern standards as far as being clean, and size of enclosures, it is a very nice zoo that seems to be doing the best it can with its resources and those efforts should be commended. Anyone saying it's too expensive for a foreigner, at $5 US to get in should be ashamed, considering the prices I've paid to get into zoos in Europe and the US. I wish the locals would respect their national treasures as much as they should, as water bottles and trash were thrown throughout, and though the guards do random checks of people's bags to assure no plastic bags get in, maybe the same rules should apply to water bottles if people can dispose of them correctly. The views of many animals allows you to get much closer than most zoos, and as I said, the Nepalese have done a good job overall considering their resources.

At the end of our last trekking holiday in Nepal our favourite Porter offered to take us to the Zoo! A manic taxi ride later and there we were. Expecting the worst we were surprised & relieved that the comfort of the animals is very important here. It is currently in the process of being updated with new paths and enclosures so I think in a few years it will be quite lovely.Great range of animals from elephants, hippo, various deer & primates. piranha and tigers to (believe it or not) white mice! Even some cockies from Australia to make us feel at home. Being the only Caucasians there that day we felt just as 'on display' as most of the exhibits!! We had a great afternoon though and will check it out again on our next trip
I had Rosemary Chicken because I was missing western style food, and I was very pleased with the meal. It was tasty and well presented, and we didn't need to wait for too long for our food to arrive.

Super friendly/helpful staff and organic Nepali coffee make this a must visit. Blended mocha was a hit. Feeling hot? They also have AC. Bonus: you can also buy a variety of beans (and ask them to be ground).

The coffee itself is pretty high quality, and they make sure to try to capitalize on that market. I have gone to TOW several times and do enjoy spending time there. It's a nice environment and has comfortable seating, air conditioning and some other luxuries.  It does bother me that it costs about twice as much for standard drinks than some of my other favorite places around Kathmandu and the quality of the drinks are not significantly higher. I paid 350 nrs ~$3.3 USD for a cappuccino, which is just about the same as I would pay in a coffee shop several orders of magnitude better in SF, Seattle or NYC.

and now there is AC in the shop to make your time as comfortable as possible along with the good food, special coffee drinks, and helpful, attentive staff .. home made baked muffins by Beth go along with any order ... stop by and tell Dale hello thanking him for the wonderful shop he has for gatherings of those who live in area and tourists coming thru that need a such a place to relax and enjoy ... the new awning also deserves attn, so when possible to sit outside ... special place in Kathmandu town ...

column7: Cozy, good for a long afternoon
column8: I went there after visiting Patan Durbar Square, you enter and feel welcome, i loved the table directly on the right side. The coffe is really good, the staff does everything to make you feel comfortable and never want to leave. I had the hot Ginger Lemon Tea (140 rupees) and a Lasagna with a side salad (500 rupees(around 4 euros) while browsing the Internet, which is pretty fast. You can stay here the whole afternoon, eat and relax after doing the touri-stuff. If you think about visiting again, they have stamp cards which you can collect with every coffe yoy drink, after 10 you get one for free.

column7: for coffee, this is amongst the best in the area
column8: There is a rash of coffee shops in the area, all influenced by expats and good in different ways. This has a good feel to it.Dale and co do a lot to create good coffee and food. The service is first class, good place to meet up. Great for an early breakfast. Not the cheapest though.

column7: Great Coffee Place, reminds me of home
column8: This is a great little place for Expats to go and have their morning joe. Good selection of coffees and breakfast. At first glance it might appear expensive but they include their service charge and tax in the price. I have enjoyed going here almost daily for the past few weeks. Good strong WiFi and like I said a good place to network with other Expats

column7: Great Coffee and Atmosphere in Kathmandu
column8: Make sure you visit Top of the World Coffee for a great cup of Nepalese coffee and delicious breakfast, lunch and dinner too! During my week in Kathmandu, I stopped for coffee on 3 different occasions and had dinner with a couple of local friends as well. Friendly and helpful staff, wonderful atmosphere, great food and really good, grown and roasted in Nepal coffee. Top of the World also features some local arts and crafts so you can purchase a souvenir or a gift for a friend while enjoying a wonderful cup of coffee while you are on 'Top of the World'.

lovely quiet place to relax and visit with family and friends, good selection of cold beverages, also the freshly ground coffee is the best ever and people come here just for it. Homemade baked brownies and muffins are delicious. The lunch was served by a friendly staff, that were attentive to our needs. Menu includes a variety of food, so that you can make a choice to your liking, Coffee can be bought in bulk amounts. Also sold are mugs and cups with saucers that have the logo of Top of the World Coffee, and they are a perfect souvenir. Music night brings a large crowd of people to hear local musicians sing and play, which all of us enjoyed very much ... make sure you stop in.
The cofee is good, the view is stupendous. I still think , I've got better impression of the Patan therefore)

Good coffee. Freshly ground drip style. A little strange atmosphere, everyone was hunched over laptops with ear buds in. Not such a social place. But fine if you like a decent cup of coffee and free internet. Food wasn't special. Wifi was slow, but this is Nepal. A little more expensive than most of the other cafes in the area. Right on the street so very dusty, but this is often the case in Kathmandu area. Don't sit outside unless you like dust in your coffee. Loved the photographs on the wall.

We've been travelling for a few weeks with our family. We stopped in at Top of the World Coffee for breakfast. Wow. We've been craving some comfort foods and tastes from home. Top of the World delivered. In addition to serving up great coffee, they have a nice selection of breakfast items. Our kids loved the plate sized pancakes. I had the American style breakfast sandwich--yum. Its hard to come by this sort of food in Asia. We plan on paying a few more visits here during our trip.  A few more things to mention: The atmosphere is pleasant. There are both tables and sitting areas. On top of having free WiFi they have surge protectors in several places to plug in your electronics. They also sell several varieties of coffee beans that they are happy to grind for you. This was a big plus for us since we brought our Aeropress along on our trip but no grinder.  Directions in Nepal can be a bit confusing. Top of the World Coffee is on the same street as The British School. Right near it. They have a big sign that you can't miss.

We came to Cafe du Temple for a mid morning cup of coffee and a cup masala chai. Service was ok and we had a lovely time sitting on the roof enjoying the view of Patan Square. Then we came downstairs to pay the bill and the staff presented us with Rupee 1950. We asked them why the bill is rather expensive for just two cups of hot drinks. They said it’s because of the gov tax and 10% service charge. We politely asked them to recalculate the bill and it came up now to the same price. So we checked the menu and did the calculation ourselves. Alas! after 13% gov tax and 10% service charge the total bill was Rupee 175. We mentioned it to the staff and they did their calculation for the third time using the same calculator and it was just Rupee 175. No apology comes with it. I would like to give them benefit of the doubt because people in Nepal are honest and friendly. Sadly the staff in this place doesn’t live to our expectations. We won’t be returning to Cafe du Temple.

column7: Service was so bad we left before eating!
column8: Our most disappointing restaurant experience in Nepal- during a month long visit. We’re not that fussy even street momos & home made Raksi you buy in the villages make this place look like such a rort! The service was unbelievably slow, only to find much of he menu was also not available. When we agreed to order a bottle of the Nepali white wine (as none of their foreign varieties listed on menu were available)- They tried to sell us a bottle which was already open.... Goodness knows for how long? After waiting 45 mins for the cocktail my fiancé ordered only to find it undrinkable, we cut our losses, paid the bill and left as quickly as possible.

As we were staying around the corner we popped into Cafe du Temple hoping to be able to grab some decent food whilst we did some people watching on Durban Square.  The menu is decent in terms of selection but unfortunately the food itself was disappointing. My other half ordered chicken chow mein which was pretty tasteless but edible. I ordered noodle soup which unfortunately turned up about 25 minutes after the chicken chow mein - not too big a deal but that too was disappointing. Having just got back from 4 days trekking I was used to eating simple but filling food, but the noodle soups I had eaten in the mountains were far better.  If you're looking for a cafe in a good location this is fine, but if you're looking for decent food which represent a value for money I'd suggest you go elsewhere.

Their chicken momo personally I think is the best momo in town. They only make it after you order this dish, so they will inform you have to wait at least half an hour, but it's worthy. They have tables in the rooftop and have big umbrellas to cover sunshine. Below 2 photos are the view from the rooftop.

We stopped here to have lunch. As it was included in our tour, I can't give any reference for the prices they have, but I assure you that the food was tasty. We had their traditional plate: Dal Bhat. In case you don't like spicy, make sure you tell them in advance. The pickles were great!

We came in as a group of 5, expecting something unique given the pretty exterior. Below average food which we were then overcharged for. Didn't feel like the place was hygienic and we definitely do not recommend. Can see some OK views from the rooftop but not worth the bill.

column7: Orange lime bomb ! Delicious ! Lovely setting too
column8: Set out the very back of the museum in a lovely garden setting, good food and service , run by the same people of the Summit. Hotel where UN people stay, so very used to westerners . If you don't feel like a full meal try the orange lime bomb, served in a hollowed out orange , with a smooth and light , mouse/ ice cream with a lime flavour that is tangy and refreshing. A lovely tucked away place to recuperate before facing the busyness of Kathmandu again.

column7: Nice place overlooking the Durbar Square in Patan
column8: This is a great place to relax over a drink and a meal while you soak in the sights of the Durbar Square. Just make sure to get yourself a table next to one of the windows on the first floor.  The food was pretty ok; they offer Continental, Chinese and Nepali at reasonable prices.  Service was polite and friendly but quite slow. Just as well as you can rest your feet and enjoy the view of the Square for a bit longer !

The inn Patan is an excellent place. In my opinion it has the best food in Nepal. The cafe serve delicious Burger, Nepali Thali, Steak, etc. The place was very clean and peaceful.the architecture of the place was kind of old Newari style. The price...More

While doing university research for 10 weeks in the kathmandu valley this was our prime lunch treasure. The tuna sandwich was awesome and worth coming back for multiple times. Even the lunch of departure day was done here! It's secluded location within busy/smoggy Kathmandu and great food make this the perfect lunch getaway when in the patan neighbourhood!

column7: Cute little place in perfect location for Patan
column8: Old beautiful building, super cute and with a nice vibe.  The location is excellent. You walk out and you are in Patan Square so for that area of the city it is ideal.  The room - we had a room up on 2nd floor looking into the courtyard. It was extremely spacious, nicely decorated, good shower and a unique style.  The staff - we didn't really interact with anybody too much but overall they were all very polite  Breakfast - very decent, ok coffee  I would definitely recommend for exploring Patan.  Tip: there is a nice organic restaurant just outside Patan Inn. Nice food and friendly staff

The Inn Patan is undoubtedly a hidden treasure of Patan. It is an example how local traditional house can be turned into a boutique Hotel.  As soon as we enter the Hotel gate, we felt that we are entering to local house but once we checked in to our room, we are amazed to see how beautifully the rooms are decorated with local touch yet blended with modern facilities.  The food and service are good. I liked the friendly staff.  We are more than happy to spend time in this hotel and highly recommend this hotel to check it out. I am sure that nobody wants to leave this place simply.  Keep it up the great work.

We stopped by to have lunch as part of our tour to Patan. It is located within the Dubar square and part of the boutique hotel. The restaurant is small but the setting is beautiful and chic. Their bathrooms are modern and clean.  Due to the fuel shortage , their menu is very limited but everything is fresh and cooked perfectly.  We had sandwiches and pasta. Everything is about 500 rubies or $5 USD. The staff is very friendly and pleasant. The chef made a special desert of pomelo (tradition of the light festival) which was not on the menu for us!  I would definitely recommend this place!

column7: Excellent food and ambiance. Great place to have business meetings, reunions with friends or breakfast/lunch/dinner.
column8: The option of inside or outside dining, varied and interesting menu, excellent service, and good location with parking make Manny's a great place to go. If you are staying at the Shaligram it is perfect and even provides room service! Plus there are foot stomping...More

This restaurant is inside the Shaligram Hotel Village. Very calm and nice with tasty options. Mostly Thai dishes but they also have a variety of other cuisines. Ask waitress if you need any other types of dishes. She will have cook make for you!

You have to go to Patan Durbar square. My advice would be if you are staying in Patan, go to see it as soon as possible. There is no need to pay for a guide (but do if you like) because all of the information is provided in books or online.  A lot of museum is about the reconstruction of it after the earthquake. But it is great to see such beautiful structures.  The square also has loads of market/shop stalls with people selling loads of stuff. Haggle and negotiate, but not too much because the prices are already quite reasonable. Beware, most of the “North face” jackets are fake, still very warm and decent quality but not good if you’re gonna go mountaineering!  Just a short walk from Durbar square is the Kumari living goddess of Patan. Go and visit her and receive Tika.

If you've been to the one in Kathmandu then this one is similar, a little smaller but somehow nicer. Go before the crowds (10am) or better still stay the night and see it in a different light. Make sure you visit the museum

column7: Extensive damage here from the earthquake but still worth a visit
column8: This is a nice square despite the earthquake damage. Our guide spent a lot of time telling us about the reconstruction, and it appears that it is going well and will look as it did before the earthquake when finished. Almost every building is propped up with huge boards to stabilize them, and large cracks are seen everywhere.  There are still plenty of beautiful carvings to see on the buildings and carved stone figures and statues throughout. We went to visit the house of the Kumari Devi (the Living Goddess). We could not go in but were allowed in the courtyard to see if she would make an appearance at a window. No photos allowed if she appeared. She did appear and looked out at everyone. This goddess is a 5 year old girl who lives apart from her family until she reaches puberty. It was quite an interesting story.  Worth a visit even though some people complained about the entrance fee. The entrance fee is worth it if this trip is something that you will probably never do again, so why not?

column7: Patan Museum is a Big Plus
column8: They say that the Patan Durbar Square is the best of all three in Nepal and after visiting the outskirts of the Kathmandu Durbar Square, I would be inclined to agree (can't completely do so since I haven't been to Bhaktapur.) I didn't enter Kathmandu Durbar Square cause of the expensive entrance fee but it seemed in complete disarray and didn't think there would be much to see.  The Patan Durbar Square also has a lot of rehabilitation going on but it's not as tight and stressful to get into as the Kathmandu one. There's a lot more space to move around and most of the main building has been preserved.  A huge plus about going to Patan Durbar Square is that it houses the Patan Museum, which is easily the best museum I've been to in Nepal. It was very informative and described facts about Hindi and Buddhist history, iconography, symbolisms, and belief systems. I really appreciated that. Because of this, you wouldn't need a tour guide anymore.  Some groups got a tour guide and they sometimes spoke loudly to be heard. Because of that, I would get some interesting new information at random and that was a nice little surprise.  I highly recommend going to this place!

Didn’t end up going in. Expensive entry for foreigners compared to other tourist spots. Nice local community around Durbar square to get a taste of local living. Quite close to Thamel - 10-12 min walk.

I got happily lost on the way to the square (no signs, or if there are they are in Nepali!!) but when I found it, it was beautiful and lived up to expectations. Yes there is a lot of construction work going on but most of the (slightly steep but undetstandsble) tourist ticket of 1000NR goes towards the rebuild. It must have been amazing prior to the earthquake. Ignore the guides touting for your business- you get a guide-leaflet and it's nice to wander at your leisure.

There are a lot of activities to reconstruct the city after the 2015 earthquake but walking around the city one can appreciate the mystical atmosphere of Patan. Start your walks from the Durbar and get a bit lost to appreciate the many beauties of the city and the central area. Absolutely not to miss in a tour of the Kathmandu valley.

It is the best representation of Nepalese art and architecture. It is very interesting ancient temple represent world heritage site. There are very interesting art about god and goddess. Some of the common monuments are Krishna Mandir, Patan durbar square, Mahabouddha, Hiranya Verna Mahavihar, Kumlwshwor.

Near the main city of Kathmandu, this is a charming place. Reminds you of a magical era that almost borders on fantasy. Accessible for a quick trip, the whole are has lots to offer, from small charming shops, to historic monuments, and great places to eat and drink.

column7: Really beautiful, but so destroyed after the earthquake
column8: Among all the tourist attractions we saw in Kathmandu, Durbar Square stays on the first place. The palace and the temples are beautiful and reflect so much the architectural style of the place. But unfortunately, we saw it after the earthquake and even after 2 years of that unhappy event, the temples are in reconstruction. Even so, it is worth a visit to take the pulse of the dusty, crazy and overwhelming Kathmandu.

column7: Most Beautiful Durbar Square in Kathmandu Valley
column8: I immensly enjoyed our privately guided tour to Patan: the Durbar Square is at leas as impressive and interesting as the Kathmandu and Baktapur one. It felt cleaner in comparison though, which might make it a better start for European tourists.
History is embedded deep within Kathmandu and the people interact with it daily in many ways. This is a good place to learn about Nepal and its history as well as how people interact today.

Like other previous reviews, we had a great time exploring culture, architectural and historical features at Patan Durbar Square. We spend almost 4 hours wandering around the area to appreciate the beauty of it until we accidentally witness a religious ceremony that perform by locals inside the temple: they behead a baby buffalo( sacrificing to some Gods). Unprepared for what was going on back then,we were in shock and the image of them pulling the next buffalo up to be beheaded(while the poor buffalo clearly shivering and hesitated to walk ahead) more or less kill the mood for the rest of the day. We were out of that temple right after seconds comprehending what was going on,very upset.  We respect the local culture and religious belief but just for the experience: if you don't want to see unexpected slaughter,as soon as you see animals (buffaloes , goats,etc at their unusual residence) +some kind of rituals going on+a crowd around it,don't look and walk away,we are sure there are lot of other ways to experience Nepal than witnessing some animals slaughtered.

I loved this place. Very typical Nepali architecture and symbolic of its tradition and the rich cultural legacy. A walk around the durbar is really awesome. And it is great to see so many people in the area still on to their ancestral trade. I went to a small restaurant in the area and had a traditional Nepali meal. The owner claimed that his family has been running the restaurant for more than 300 years. Amazing.  This place is a visual treat. I would recommend all tourists to visit this place.
We went here and they chase you down and try to make you pay but you’re better off not paying and just snapping a few pics before they want you out.

Go to Pagan Durbar Square, see the cruel fate of nature; the damaged buildings, the work of man over the centuries dashed in minutes by natural forces. It is a cruel world yet the square bustles with people, regeneration can be seen, the spirit of man is not broken, like a phoenix rising from the ashes. It is still awe inspiring and provided tourists continue to visit it will one day regain its full splendour. If we fail to visit we'll fail both the past and the future generations as repairs will not be completed.

Patan durbar square one of the getaway place for most residents in lalitpur nepal. I visit yhis place now and then... There is something mystical about this place... My favourite place to sit is above the sweet shop which is at the centre of 'mangalbazaar' (aka) : just opposite to the entry checkpost. The entrance fee for foreigners is nrs.500, a bit less for asians. Sitting there and going in depth with the monuments and admiring the beauty of historical architecture, a deep breath and a hot coffee is all you need to connect to your soul.... Hundreds of people come and go... Observing them is another means of entertainment... You can also feed pigeons inside durbar square.... Its a place not to miss if you are in patan. Renivatikms are ongoing... The earthquake has affected and demolished a few temples... However it still holds the beauty that describes nepali culture... you can never get enough of this place... B it alone or chitchatting with your friends you can go on for hours and hours....

In Patan Durbar Square, its like stepping in a new world after a few steps away from your ride. Terra-cotta colors are everywhere and you are brought back to the ancient time.  The Carvings are exquisite, the arts are amazing. the colors are good for the eye and will make you want to wonder on how talented the people from before are.

Wonderful spot to visit to get a sense of the ancient kingdoms that underpinned modern- day Nepal. Wonderful architecture and woodwork, sculptures and temples. Always lots of community members, hawkers, gawkers and other tourists around. Nearby markets upmarket and low-key shopping and lots more. Some of the buildings destroyed in the 2015 earthquake are undergoing restoration - note the plaques describing before and after and support received. I did not have a guide but given the fascinating concentration of structures history and culture - this would probably be well worthwhile. Worth a visit anytime you are in Kathmandu. See my pictures @antzsydney and here.

Patan Darbar Square is listed on the World Heritage Site. There are many Pagoda style temples and visit to inner court , with a wide array of stone and wood craving is stunningly beautiful. One of the remarkable monuments in Patan Durbar square is a 17th century temple dedicated to the Hindu God Krishna. The temple is built entirely on stone. Visit to inner bahal and courtyard gives you a wonderful experience to see the daily life of its inhabitants.
Culture and religious center with many centuries old buildings which reflect unique architectural features like intricately carved teak wood panels and elaborate doors posts.

This is about a 600-800Rp taxi ride from Thamel and well worth the effort to get here. It costs 1000Rp for foreigners. From a damage point of view the temples etc have suffered a bit, but not as bad as Kathmandu's Durbar square. Across the road from the pay station there is a raised terrace that affords you a great view of the complex. As I said most of the area is intact but the Hari Shankar Mandir has gone, the Yoganarendra Malla Pillar is up, but behind scaffoldng, the Jagan Narayan Mandir is gone, the Krishna Mandir is heavily scaffolded but they let you in, and the Manimandapa Mandir(?) is gone. That said it is a cool spot to visit and much less "commercial" than Kathmandu. The Patan Museum is definitely worth visiting - lots of nice historical exhibits. You also get to walk round the Royal Palace.

Enjoy the great view of the temples during sun down and blend in with the local community who come out to stroll in the evening. The museum is excellent and offers many exhibits. New areas of the Patan Durbar is being opened. Do not forget to go to Mulchowk.

We took a taxi from Thamel and spent 400 rupees to get there. Only about 10 to 15 minutes drive. If you asked me to choose either going this or Durbar Square, I would pick here. The place was not as crowded as Durbar Square and has a lot to see although both places have a lot of buildings closed for reconstruction. The laundry and washing place with free flow of water supply is worth to have a look to get the taste of the local living style.

We gladly paid the entrance fee and then we were worked by a local guide and finally caved. He was knowledgable and this did enhance our experience but then we found ourselves at "the singing bowl guy" and "the mandala guy", although this may be true, both had prices well above anywhere else. The area of historical interest is actually quite small. It wasn't as spectacular as I had imagined.

column7: Told one thing at gate entrance, then threatened by another worker
column8: We arrived in Bhaktapur by bus and came upon the first entrance gate we saw. We told the gentlemen we just wanted to go to our hotel and asked him for directions. We had our packs on and wanted to set those down and rest prior to visiting the square and other sites. He told us our hotel was to the right and we could go that way without paying. To the left was the entrance area to pay. We went to the right as we just wanted to get to our hotel. 5 minutes into walking we were approached by a man asking for our tickets. We didn't have any. With aggression, he demanded that we paid even though we weren't going to enter the square and we were taking backroads to our hotel around the square and tourist areas. We told him what his co-worker told us and he didn't believe us. We didn't want to go all the way back to the entrance to pay, as we already had walked all the way around. He held us there and threatened to call the police...REALLY???? His boss came. At this point it was unbelievable being told one thing and then getting threats for being told the way to go without paying. We are happy to pay fees and help the economy but don't need to be threatened to do so. There needs to be clearer guidelines here and consistency. Being mislead and then threatened is not a good first impression to this area.

column7: A Small, Ancient Royal Palace Rich in Religious Arts
column8: Only 20-30 minutes by car from Kathmandu, Patan's preserved royal palace (durbar square) was the oldest and smallest compared to Kathmandu's and Bhaktapur's and less crowded. There's a south-north, brick-paved pedestrian road to explore. On the left row, you'll see 7 pagoda temples (Krishna, Harishankar, Vishnu, Jagannarayan, Krishna -the main one, Bhimsen and Vishwonath), a huge bell (Taleju) and metal statues of 3 Malla kings on tall monuments. On the right side, royal palaces with courtyards (Sundari Chowk - with sunken bath, Mul Chowk and Mani Keshar Chowk), the Golden Temple & Museum, 3 other temples (Taleju, Degutale, Mani) and the ancient water source, Manga Hiti. Small fees applied to enter the palaces and museum on top of the square's entrance ticket of NPR 500/US$ 5, but it's worth it. There were residential and commercial buildings surrounding and inside the square. We spent a few hours strolling down this historical site, relaxing at temples' stairs and taking lots of photos (visited 2 weeks prior to the devastating earthquake last year).

column7: Still to recover from the earthquake but a lovely place
column8: We greatly enjoyed Patan and its Durbar square. It is well kept, with a sacred temple every meter basically. All very interesting, even though not all allow entry to non-Hindus. Sadly, the place was also quite badly hit from the earthquake and this is still visible around the square. Hopefully, the entrance fee will somehow help its quicker recovery. In all cases, it is still very much worth a visit. Make sure to also walk around the square, into the market streets and experience the place to its fullest.

We were prepared for a Kathmandu recovering from earthquake. We were prepared for a nation faithfull and away from modern world. But somehow, when i stepped in Durbar Square , saw that dust everywhere........ my eyes got dusty. İn the pictures i could see how should be the temple i was looking at, wonderfull craft, authentic architecture,years of work but in front of me was a mountain of bricks. That moment i wished i would come years before. İ am sure by the time things can recover , but this spring Durbar Square looked dust in the wind. We decided to drink a coffee somewhere upstairs to admire the view of Durbar Square. The place we choosed was at minimum level we are used with, but surprised us with a real cold beer, things difficult to achieve in some parts of Europe.

So glad we took the taxi from Thamel out to Patan the scene of century old structures was incredible and a must do for any visit to Kathmandu Valley. The taxi trip was NPR500 so dont pay more! The entry fee is NPR1000 quite steep but if you are visting Nepal you'll only see bis place once Next time you'd sneak in the back entrance where there are mo ticket offices. Just make sure you leave that way or the guide touts that hang by the main entrance will spot you and could cause embarrassment

column7: By Going Now - you support post-earthquake restoration
column8: Nepal's massive earthquake and aftershock was one year-ago. The is the perfect time to visit Kathmandu and the nearby, world heritage site of the old city centre of Patan's, Durbar Square. A trip there is now especially gratifying, as the local economy is heavily dependent on tourism, which has significantly fallen from pre-earthquake days. From Kathmandu, it is an easy, thirty minute taxi ride to this living museum. While there is evidence of earthquake damage, most of the splendid buildings remain intact. There is a palpable vibrancy and optimism that adds to the energy of the place. Walking amidst the magnificently carved ancient wooden temples is a powerful experience. The very impressive Patan Museum in the historic town centre is not be missed. (And the delicious veggie momos in the museum's terrace café make for a splendid break!)

column7: Worth a visit while in the city
column8: The earthquake devastated this local architectural wonder. That said, there is still enough here to make it worth the visit. Save the tuk-tuk fee and enjoy a 20-30 minute walk from Thamel.  The entrance fee is 1000 rupees for foreigners (~$12) - while you can easily avoid paying, it is much needed for the restoration of the site.

column7: THIS IS A MUST IF VISITING KTM!
column8: Come for the architecture , art and local charm. Be prepare to be touched an chewer broken at the devastation from the earthquake--but also the spirit of the Nepalese..  Eat some Newari food- try some Newari beer or Newari wine..  Stroll through these stress and every corner there is something to marvel at.such detail in everything and care. The Hindu and Buddhists temples are awe inspiring.  Do not miss!

Old town with old architecture which is still intact post earthquake. You see certain buildings and school destroyed by earthquake but still the spirit of the people keeps the place alive and buzzing.

column7: Less busy than Kathmandu Durbar Square
column8: I really enjoyed visiting this square and felt it was really worth a visit, despite the earthquake damage. It was a lot less busy than Kathmandu Durbar Square, which made it easier to relax and enjoy the environment and hear about the history of the square (well worth hiring a guide for this). The surrounding areas have lots of local artisans who do metal work, so it is worth a wander around here (if only to admire their skills, even if you don't buy anything).
Everybody knows that lalitpur is the city of Art . This ancient city is famous for metal art. All temples are really beautiful with Newari art and style .

The most important monument of the city is Patan Durbar Square, which has been listed by UNESCO as one of seven Monument Zones that make up the Kathmandu Valley World Heritage Site. The seven monument zones were included in the World Heritage List in 1979 as one integrated site. The monument zones are declared as protected and preserved according to the Monuments Preservation Act of 1956. The Square was heavily damaged on 25 April 2015 by an earthquake

column7: Not a good time to visit
column8: Because of the earthquake, there is heavy damage and some construction. The poles holding up the temple and other buildings make it hard to get around. Surely this was spectacular before the earthquake. Now, not so much.

This square is beautiful and really lights up at night with locals coming out to socialise and make the most of the square. We loved sitting here at dusk soaking it all in. If you don't want to pay the entrance fee just go in any of the other entrances where there is no ticket collector.

One of the best places to be. Has a wonderful blend of History, Architecture, Temples and peace. A place where you would love to end your day with a coffee or just a stroll with all by yourself or with family and friends.

column7: I'm praying that the country recovers
column8: I was able to visit Durbar Square before the earthquake shook the area. Nepal is beautiful and the people are lovely. I can only hope they can recover soon.

Walking around the square takes one back to a time where life was less chaotic.  Make sure to purchase your ticket before you go into the various buildings. I had the fortune to actually see a taping of a show where the actors all wore period costumes. It was a sight to behold. To see people dressed in costumes amidst the setting, it was definitely an experience.  The place was crowded during my visit, but in spite of the crowd, once can still feel the history emanating from within the walls of this sacred place.

column7: Even after the earthquake worth visiting!
column8: This square is unbelievable. First time to visit and was mesmerized. As someone mentioned before, you feel like you went back in time!

You will feel on the sets of a Hollywood blockbuster or if more imaginative, the place will take you 200 years back in a blink of eye. Spare and spend some time sitting in a corner and imagining life of that time. The place does not look like a historical monument because life goes on in around it.

column7: you have to go there - now!
column8: i know there was the big earthquake, i have been there, but really: you have to go there, make your staff ready and leave! first of all its still awesome, and second my friends need your money ;-)

column7: Good place to visit and easy to access from Kathmandu
column8: This square is very much worth a visit as it is only a 20 - 30 minute taxi journey from Kathmandu. There are a number of historic temples including some extraordinary erotic (and not for the faint-hearted!) carvings on one of the temples in a traditional South Asian style. The square also houses the Patan Museum, which is simply amazing. It is easy to walk from here to the nearby Mahabuddha temple. There are fairly regular religious processions and performances in the square as well. Overall, I strongly recommend a visit to this square and the surrounding historic neighborhood - many of the buildings are remarkably old, featuring period carvings and architecture.

column7: Historic Square with an authentic feel, far far better than Kathandus Durbar Sq
column8: We visited the Durbar Sq in Patan the day after we visited the one in Khatmandu and the difference is immense. You still have to pay to get into the area of the Square - but all the sourrounding streets are far more welcoming and you are treated as less of a target for touts etc etc in this square.  A relativeley small area the square is a rectangular shaped area bordered on one side by the old Palace and on the other side of a wide thoroughfare are a variety of temples. The locals transit through the square and it does have a genuine local feel to it.  Unlike Kathmandu this square is blocked off for cars and mopeds, and it does look like they have spent some of the entrance fee on improving the infrastructure.  Concidering the short distance from the centre of Khatmandu I would thoroughly reccomend a trip here - it's a far better Durbar Sq (Although not quite as good as Bhaktapurs).

For this attraction it is a good idea to get a local guide when you pay your entry fee. Remember, these attractions demand payment from foreigners but not locals. Negotiate with the guide first though. I paid 1/2 of what my guide was asking. In addition, confirm how much time they will be spending with you. The reason to get a guide is to ensure you find the Buddhist Golden Temple which is hidden down some side streets from the primarily Hindu buildings. 500 Rupees for entry fee. The architecture is very cool and about 500 years old. The Golden Temple is worth the extra 50 Rupees entrance fee. Gold-plated and from the 12th century. Be ready to say 'no' to being taken to more shops as that is common with these guides who receive a kickback.

column7: Best of the Three Durbar Squares
column8: Part of seven archeological and historic UNESCO sites in Kathmandu Valley, Patan Durbar Square is a must see. Westerners pay a higher entry ticket price (roughly 1000Rs), but the day-ticket can be extended for several days until the end date of your visa if you bring it to show at the ticket counter. This square seems to be the center of business as well, so taxis from here are easy to find. Don't miss the museum and the Museum Cafe! You may be approached for tours of the area that usually start at 1200Rs, but negotiate hard. Some tour guides will take you to Tibetan shops to sell you singing bowls and paintings--all beautiful and whatnot, but steeply overpriced. Be sure to negotiate very low for these if you do want to purchase. Otherwise, don't cave in to pressure or let your guide know you aren't willing to buy before entering.

This is the smallest of the three Durbar Squares (the other two being Kathmandu Darbar Square and Bhaktapur Durbar Square) in the Kathmandu Valley. Yet it is very pleasing to the eyes and one can spend a few hours here in peace. Do make it a point to read about the monuments before hand. Or you could take a local guide. TIPS: During your tour of the museum, do make it a point to climb up the Bell Tower. It is an easy climb up a flight of stairs. And the view is great. The Ticket for entry to the Square is valid for one day. However, you can request for an extension of upto a week at no extra cost. Show your passport, and they will endorse your ticket.

This square blows the one in Kathmandu out of the water. The architecture here is incredible and it has a top class museum within it as well. Standing net to the buildings gives you the feeling of going back in time. It's simply amazing. Make sure your camera battery is charged!

If you cannot get to Bactapur, Patan will show you what old Nepalese architecture and regal style existed once upon a time. Elegance and spatial design provide a real wow factor. Add nearby boutique hotels, good eating options, laneways and retail to the mix for a pleasant half day experience

column7: Wonderful medieval temples, carvings and statues
column8: We hired a local guide....unnecessary, in retrospect, and in some ways a mistake. The buildings speak for themselves (or take your own guide book/pamphlet) but he did explain some of the social/cultural/historical stuff that makes the place make sense. He also contrived to take us to two workshops....and fascinating though they both were, there was some pressure to buy. So, if you are with your Nepal tour guide you should be ok but otherwise be firm with local guides about where you want to go and what you want to discover. Plus, there's a fantastic café/restaurant within one of the courtyards with lovely gardens...a perfect place to chill out in this otherwise busy part of the city. The wood and stone carvings are astonishing.

Patan is one of the ancient capitals in Kathmandu Valley and has a splendid temple complex in its Durbar Square. Founded in the 3rd century, Patan is also called Lalitpur or 'Beautiful City'. According to my guidebook, there are 55 major temples in this city alone and 136 courtyards many of which make this beautiful section of the city a photographer's paradise.  We strolled through this marvelous square and spent about three hours enjoying the sights, sounds, smells, and colors of this magnificent World Heritage site. We started with the Royal Palace to our right and moved on to the Sacred Well just beyond. The water that comes out of the spouts comes from a water source miles away. There is the pillar surmounted by a gilt statue of King Yoganarendra Malla shaded by the hooded cobra that hovers over him and the simply splendid Krishna Mandir with its colonnades and porches and a huge dome over all.  I really wish I had the time to come back here because there is so much to see that I probably overlooked a lot. On the day of our visit, the square was very crowded because there was an election rally with thousands of people waving flags and listening to the speakers. There were pilgrims and monks visiting the religious sites and temples, shoppers bustling about, and tourists dining at cafes and restaurants. The place has an energy level that can't be beat.  We also moved on to the Golden Temple in the north part of town. Again, very exciting. See my photos as these are worth a thousand words. Note that there is a small fee to enter this area of the city. Pay it without complaint as it helps to preserve this marvelous complex.

A must visit place like any other cultural attraction in Nepal. It is not much different as style than other Durbar Squares but you must go there. Near the square you can walk through narrow streets like no other places. Be aware of so-called "official guides" as they are annoying... otherwise, you can hire them very cheap but no guaranty of the quality of the info... Like any other places there are tickets and they are like contribution not as mandatory ... like that ;)

column7: A good happening place in Patan
column8: I went to this place along with my friends and course mates as a part of a cultural outing. Before we were there, we didn't know what to expect for and then we were there, we were like, 'wow'. The atmosphere around the place is nice and has an ancient vibe in the wind. There are clothes attached to the roofs of the castles which dances as the wind blows which gives a feeling of peace. There are plenty of food stalls around. The day we were there hosted a public performance on interactive theater by this local group. I would recommend people to visit this place if they have the opportunity to.  Oh and there are admission fees to enter this facility. The rate however is different for the natives, South Asian citizens and others. I do not remember exactly but I think we paid 150 NPR (US$ 1.5) for South Asian passes.

If the hanuman dhoka durbar square has unique combination of malls and shah period architecture,patan durbar square on the other hand reflects singular malla architecture.It has a unique architecture style manga hiti,the sunken stone water spout and the magnificent Krishna temple,a shikhara style temple built of stone are really perfect.  I enjoy a lot, visiting different courtyard of patandurbar square.The mangalbazar where square lies is very good place to see the monument and different arts and different temple in different style. I love to visit and enjoy this place so i often loke to visit here when i am in Kathmandu.

Patan's Durbar square truly deserves it's World Heritage status. It is an amazing collection of Buddhist and Hindu buildings. Patan / Lalitpur is 15 minutes drive from Kathmandu south across the Bagmati River. Its a wonderful place to wander for a couple of hours, with no cars in your way. There is a ticket kiosk at the entrance to the square, it costs 500rs and you have to wear a sticker. Around the entrance there are pushy people wanting to be your guide, even small children are in on the act. One said to me "sooner or later you will have to give in". You don't need a guide, I found them so persistent I headed straight for a rooftop café called Café du Temple and just sat there reading about the square and viewing it from afar. The square can be very relaxing if you find your own secluded spot. Children play badmington, people wash their clothes in a nearby well. Make sure you set aside a couple of hours for the museum. Look out for some Bull's instestines hanging over a door near the museum.

After visiting Durbar Square in Kathmandu the square in Patan, although the buildings are of the same style, it feels a million miles away. If you are staying in the area, I would recommend this, Ask them to stamp your ticket on the back, you will need your passport for this, your ticket then lasts a week so you can visit or walk through the square as often as you want. Make sure you keep your ticket with you, staff are around checking and if you can't show it you will be taken to the ticket booth. Take time to wander through the side streets and see a little more of Patan, there are some great value little craft shops. We had some wooden gifts made to bring home for a really reasonable price and watching the craftsmen work on them made them extra special. Great for people watching and watching life go by.

Patan Durbar square is likely the easiest to get around, well maintained and less chaotic then the other durbar squares. You can even stay in any of the hotels in the larger area with easy access to modern amenities just a few minutes away. In short, it is the closest to being a living, breathing museum with as less touristy features as can be possible in such historic sites. Think of a mini Angkor Tham without an international company selling the whole package to you. There are actual people who live and breathe within these grounds same as they did thousands of years ago.

There are two, if not three, Durbar (or Darbar) Squares in what one thinks of as Kathmandu. This Durbar Square is, however, in Patan which, at one time, would have been separate from old Kathmandu. Kathmandu has extended so much it has now swallowed areas that might have, historically, been townships in their own right.  Patan Durbar Square has more impressive temples and historic sights than its counterpart in Kathmandu. Don't visit Nepal without seeing both, however, as each has something to offer.  A pleasant thing about Durbar Square is that one isn't hassled, or at least not too much, by persons offering to act as a guide, sell one souvenirs, etc. Be sure to bargain with taxi drivers, as they will almost inevitably try and overcharge you. The same applies to shops and stalls selling handicrafts, Pashmina shawls and souvenirs. One can end up paying very considerably less than what the seller initially demands. A good time to buy is nearing the end of the day. Traders find it hard to avoid the temptation to make one last sale and some real bargains can be obtained in these circumstances.

Make sure your batteries on the camera are charged as there are many photos to be taken here. Although it make seem similar to other temple complexes around Kathmandu, the air here is buzzing with locals enjoying. Chat and meeting up with friends. There is a vibrancy to this location that makes it a real attraction. The museum here is a must see, and there are few hawkers or guides here to hassle you, although they will ask, they are happy when you politely decline there services. It is easy to wander around. We were there on a Friday and there were several school groups were about. A little walk from the main square is the Kumbheshwor temple. Here we came across a school group playing games with their teachers. They were all having fun that it is became a real highlight of the day.

Try to visit this place when you have some spare time. The temple at the square is very old and the carvings are erotic. Have a good look. Vendors and shopkeepers do not overcharge if you can bargain. I find it bad that western tourists have to pay to visit this place when anybody else can walk in and out. School kids are everywhere, one cannot take a decent picture of a monument or statue without some kids sitting on it. This was the same in Bahktapur where I had regretted that I had paid 10 euro when I saw that so many walked in without paying. A visit to the museum still has to be paid extra anyway. In Patan, they try to avoid that people walk in without paying (only if you look western, speaking of discrimination) by obliging you to hang the large ticket around your neck. Just awful. It spoiled my appreciation of this wonderful old place, having this thing around my neck. I felt like an animal for sale. Why not make the entrance free for all without discrimination and charge for separate visits of the temple, the museum, etc... Tourists are more than just milk cows that are only good for their money.

This square, a short distance from Kathmandu is how I imagined a temple square to be. It is well preserved and is less chaotic than Kathmandu, although still crowded.
