Not awful, just completely average.  We've been to SC for brunch and dinner. Here's the breakdown:  Brunch:  We were the only table. Coffee and juice came out relatively promptly. Waiter disappeared for the next 30-45 hour or so. My wife's food came out, then mine 10 minutes later. Her eggs and bacon were okay. The sausage gravy on my biscuits tasted a bit of mucous. Wouldn't order again.  Dinner:  We were one of 3 tables. Drinks came out quickly enough. Food came out in a timely manner as well, though the concept of a 'starter' was lost to the staff, as everything hit the table at once. The burger is probably the best I've had in Patan, but that's still not as good as the worst burger I've had in other countries. The wings were fried within an inch of their lives, so all you really taste is sauce around the wilted crispy skin that remains on the bone.  I would go to SC again in a pinch, especially if I were dying for a beef burger, but I'm in no hurry. I was disappointed, after reading so many favorable reviews about the place. You pay "Western style" prices but get very average results.

i went there as they claim maxican specialty but the menu is poor per my taste, most of the dishes are between continental and fast-food. i didn't like it... also, the drinks are not natural at all, my lemonade was bad enough to make me not go there any more...
Had great food and good ambiance inside and out, but my attraction was the piano at the front pouch. I loved serenading to some jazz on my own. Cool place

On a recent Saturday, my wife and I were shopping at Bhat-Bhateni Supermarket at Krishna Galli and decided to walk up to Jhamsikel for lunch. We both had the same thought as we walked directly to the newish Southern Comfort restaurant near Saint Mary’s school without our usual discussion about where we want to lunch.  Southern Comfort’s menu is all American. Burgers, onion rings, Caesar salad, chicken-fried steak, biscuits and gravy. You get the idea. We ordered onion rings and a burger with chilies and cheese. The establishment’s owner stopped by and explained that to get a true American flavor he had to make many of the items we take for granted from scratch. He and his staff bake the hamburger buns, produce their own mayonnaise and home make the ranch dressing. The results are nothing short of spectacular for Nepal.  The onion rings were the first we’ve had during our two years in Nepal and the burger the best we’ve tasted in Kathmandu. Southern Comfort’s got all the American details just right. Our beer was even served ice cold in a frosty mug. Welcome home.
Modern air-conditioned mall - nice selection (about 20 flavours) of ice creams and sorbets. Good value for money, and good quality ice cream.

column7: Good food coupled with a lively ambience
column8: Yellow Pomelo sets an impression from the moment you enter the lively premises. For seating, options are plenty from the lively bar-side outdoors, airy terrace to the cozy indoor lounges. The staffs are an attentive lot and were constantly on standby during our visit. Apart...More
Small quiet modern clean, very friendly staff and owner, good food for very moderate prices. Nice terrace

As we pulled up a chair at Cibo, the first thing I noticed was the clean tablecloth. The second thing that came to mind was that we’ve probably been in Nepal too long when the first thing I notice is a clean tablecloth…  Looking up from the tablecloth and around Cibo’s tastefully decorated dining room, I leaned back, relaxed and enjoyed the pop music playing softly in the background. Our waiter arrived with the specials board, walked us through the options and retired to allow us to make our decisions. My wife settled on lamb cutlets, I on pepper steak (peppered steak would be more appropriate as it turns out). The wine arrived and finally (!) it was Friday.  On this Friday, we had Cibo to ourselves. Presently, we heard the mouthwatering sound of grilling meat from the open kitchen. A tempting aroma followed. On cue the waiter delivered a bowl of peanuts as a pre-dinner snack.  After a reasonable wait, our waiter returned with dinner. The presentation was among the best I’ve seen in Nepal. Grilled meat, arugula salad and roasted potatoes thoughtfully arranged and carefully presented. The taste lived up to the presentation. The steak, ordered medium, was cooked just so. The lamb was juicy and served with a pesto garnish.  As it turned out, Cibo was an excellent choice to end our week. The establishment’s refined décor, good service and better food made for a thoroughly enjoyable evening. Cibo is the complete package.

Go there only if you have all the time in the world to wait for your order to come. This cafe serves south Indian food made in its own style. My advise is to stick to Nepalese varieties in this place.

column7: Fun place with some unexpected and welcome surprises
column8: This cute place is two stories - kids will love going up the small spiral staircase to get upstairs. The breakfast menu is fairly simple - Masala omelet and hash browns are good - be prepared for a LOT of bacon with your meal! The coffee is average. I preferred the dinner when I came a year and a half ago, with lots of variety and a "chili fries" dish that will blow your mind it's so good. The moms are great, too. Don't be surprised if the servers hand you a menu and have you point at what you want. With the exception of a couple of managers, the servers are all hearing impaired. Don't let this be a cause for concern, though - their service and attention to your dining needs make many other restaurant servers pale in comparison.

column7: Great place and cause to support
column8: I visited this cafe to have a drink before making the walk back to Kathmandu from Patan. It was without doubt the best service I have received since being in Nepal. From the minute I walked in the waiter went out of his way. I couldn't get the wifi to connect downstairs so he checked with his bosses to see if I could go upstairs (which was being reserved for a function). He then took me upstairs and regularly checked to make sure everything was ok. I didn't eat so can,t comment on food but had a lemon honey tea which was delicious. Great staff, all smiling and seemed very comfortable and happy at their work. In a city as developing as Kathmandu was fantastic to see a place where deaf Nepalise are given the opportunity to provide a first class service.

My friend Megh and I dropped by this restaurant for lunch as we were in the vicinity. For a while I could not remember the name of this place located at a roundabout, however the deaf employees made a mark. I always commend establishments who employ differently-abled people and for this I gave them a 4-star rating. The ground floor was full so we dined at the second floor. One of their waitresses took our order. I had the delicious spicy momos and my friend had the fish steak, which according to him was also good. Having read the other reviews, I guess it's just ordering the right stuff to notch things up. Place is clean at the time we visited and service is quite ok (perhaps we were not too demanding). However, the food did take a longer time to reach our table. Nevertheless, it is still a good place for a light meal in the area. As usual, when in Nepal, please make sure to tip well out of kindness.

I have travelled the world and have never been served such disgusting, sickening food. The wifi didn't work and the menu was out of date. When It came to paying every price was higher. It's an absolute scam and when I complained about the food we were basically told - Unlucky. Even my ex wife could make better food than this, save yourself the hassle of wasting money on food you will not like and eat a cheesy toenail instead. You will enjoy it much more than the food here.

column7: Simple Malay/Singapore fare but great cheese cakes
column8: The menu is extensive with simple, chinese/malaysian style food (noodles, rice, stirfried etc). Food tastes ok but nothing special. However, the BIG PLUS are their cheesecakes.

column7: Amazing food.. reminds me of Singapore..
column8: Good food.. a bit expensive but worth it... Reminds me of the essence of Malaysian and Singaporean food

I do not really like the food in Nepal. I tried the japanese food, the korean, the chinese, the western, the Nepalese and I think they are all sort of average. Well, except for the food in a Tibetan restaurant I tried in Thamel, which is really good. Being a Malaysian, seeing this restaurant is like seeing water in a desert. At first, I thought this is the usual food court I saw in Malaysia or Singapore but no. They are actually a restaurant. I was told the owner here is actually a Malaysian. Most of the food in the menu are those foods you can find from the Malaysia or Singapore food courts i.e. fried kuey teow, nasi lemak, ayam rendang , roast chicken rice and etc. I ordered two dishes i.e. fried stuff tofu with chicken and prawn egg - the malaysian chinese style. They were actually not bad at all. A satisfied meal on my last night in Nepal. Highly recommended to Malaysians or Singaporeans who are craving for food back home.

I went there for breakfast, stayed to meet work mate and then ended up having lunch all it the same stay :). Good varieties of Malaysian and Singaporean cuisine, enjoyed the tastes. The restaurant is clean and well maintained and service was good. Make sure you ask for filter water, not automatic. Where cheap food can mean risk - this place is cheap and quality. Will be back there for sure whenever I'm in Kathmandu.
Good services by a team of staff who speak and understand English well. Try their cheese cakes and Indian roti! Also Singapore style fried rice noodle.

We first tried their snacks and enjoyed them. So we came back for a real meals later on, and this time we were a bit disapointed. The servings were rather small. My dish was a little too salty, my friend's one was a lot too salty. That was more "okay food" than great food. Their "New York style" cheesecake is really good as per Nepalese standards. They don't bring you water automatically, we had to ask each time we went, not so pleasant when you are thirsty and tired on a hot day ! So mixed feelings, but definitively not a "must try" for us.

column7: a burst of flavour from Singapore/Malaysia in Nepal
column8: walked for a few hours from thamel to find this restaurant. refreshingly quick service reminiscent of restaurants in singapore, very modern, clean and comfortable dining area. awesome food tasting of home which satisfied my food cravings after a month of lodge food. tried the charkwayteow, nasi lemak, soyabean milk and a la carte food for pengcai. all good! chicken rice could have had a stronger flavour though

Located about 15 minutes walk southeast of Patan Durbar square, this is a small temple built in terracotta shikara style in 14th cent. having 1000 statues of Buddha. Still under repair after the 2015 earthquake.

One of the masterpiece work on terracotta shikara style Buddhist temple in kathmandu valley that build in 14th century AD. Mahaboudha mean many boudha the temple is completely covered by 1000 one thousand statue of boudha. A group of business men who visited India in14th century and thought to introduce unique terracotta to the people of valley. This temple is located in lalitpur about 15 minutes walk from patan Durbar square to east south inside courtyard. Worth to visit for travelers who love artictecture.

one of the oldest temple where we can find religious harmony between hindu and budhist. the mandala at the ceiling of the gate is so awsome and the roof of the temple plated with gold that wil surely make u say wow atleast once

When I entered into the area of this temple, I was shocked...really!!! I had never imagined that such temple exist even in Nepal...it is really a unique and beautiful temple. It has 1000 Buddha statues .. A best temple, architecture, design... For me.

This is a small shrine tucked away in an alley near the Patan Durbar Square. We were told that this temple was originally a smaller replica of the temple at Bodh Gaya in India. Then in the 1934 earthquake, the temple collapsed and was reconstructed. There is an entry fee of NPR 30 for SAARC nationals. Please note that this same ticket is also valid at the Rudravarna Mahavihara too.
10 minutes from the main Durbar Square, gives one a real sense of a working Buddhist Temple. Light a butter lamp and make a prayer!

column7: Similar to Asan in Ktm but more laid back, great for shoes
column8: This is a typical local market area where you can buy everything for the household as well as clothing and shoes. Patan is known as the place for shoes so there is a great variety of shoe shops. It is similar to Asan in Kathmandu but there isn't as much traffic which makes for a more relaxing shopping experience. At the entrance of the market there is a bakery where you can buy Nepali style donuts, also there is a shop selling local snacks such as titaura(sweet-spicy dried fruit) and masala potato chips.

Its a nice restaurant if you want to enjoy live program. Popular Nepali singers and bands perform here. The room where band performs is bit small but one can enjoy the closeness with the musicians. However when we asked for waters to add in our...More

Nice personell and great food. Befare dining you can relax in a comfortable bar. All modern and clean. They even have an extra area for children to play. Nice outdoor area - inside diveded in a non-smoking and smoking area.

column7: Perfect Place to enjoy fantastic Newari Food in a Clean Ambience
column8: The food is fantastic by taste. Have eaten here a few times over the last years and the quality of their food is consistent. The place is bright, and clean and very trendy and modern for Nepalese restaurants. Could be in Rome, London or New York! The service provided is excellent. Especially Rajesh.  Lovely garden and beautiful bar . This place is frequented by Nepalese youngsters and must not be missed when visiting Patan

I go to Redmud mostly for work-meetings. I love the Nepalicano coffee (one of its kind), I love the ambience especially out in the garden and I love the fact that I can work when I'm there. The waiters are also really sweet and make...More

column7: Excellent quality of food. Highly recommend.
column8: This place has one of the best food anywhere in Kathmandu. The quality of food exceeded our expectations. Since we were a large group we ordered almost everything on the menu and everything we ordered was to our liking and for me especially the Risotto with white sauce. Good ambience, good food and excellent selection of wines. Service could be a bit better but can't complain too much.

Our group of friends made this our home base in Kathmandu this month. Can’t say enough about the friendly and competent staff. Great location - and we liked everything they served in the coffee shop. We also went with Five14 Adventures for a number of memorable tour days.

column7: They really try to make you feel at home :)
column8: I stayed at Five 14 for about 2 weeks while visiting in Kathmandu. SUPER friendly staff who genuinely care about their guest's well being. They were always asking how I was and if I needed anything. Clean rooms, beds and bedding are all super comfortable. The King beds are the most comfortable (my son was there and he slept on a twin and then tried the king). Hot showers are wonderful and the laundry service was nice to have. Wifi is nice and strong. They can change your money and provide SIM cards. which was very convenient. There is heat and A/C. You can walk to LOTS of great restaurants and there is a great market up on the corner with wonderful things like Gatorade :). The cons are that because there is a restaurant on the first floor, you will be hard pressed to

column7: Good location but expensive for momo
column8: This place is a good location to have lunch..the food were nice also (i choose nepali food only) but no fresh juice..but momo here quite expensive because i went to other resturent, the price is more cheaper than this place....the rest is ok  Also, dont judge by the skin too because im not nepali person even do i look like one of them because some waitress tot im nepali (because i can speak basic nepali) & they told me to move down stair if i need wifi (which im speechless) until i dont want to order again (because the food were nice) even i paid already...im so disappointed at the end
We tried two Newari dishes, they were very good and tasty. The kind staff and the great view make this place worth a visit.

I have many good experience at this resort, that is before the earthquake that destroyed the tower block. It is sad to see the whole tower block leveled after the quake and left empty. The resort is also showing its' age. Frankly it requires refreshing makeover. I was assigned a chalet where its heater/aircon unit was not working. The 7 degree night gave me little rest. Though they supplied a portable heater that blows hot air into the ceiling of a very large room, the room remained cold. I had to go to bed skipping my daily shower! Overall the property is still beautiful. But journey there through broken road is not pleasant and the aged rooms did not make the trip memorable.

I injured my lower back and the massage definitely helped. I wanted to give this a 5-star review, but can't for a few reasons.  Although the towels were clean, the cover on the neck pillow and the sheet under the towel felt clammy and weird, both being made of some awful synthetic stretchy stuff with obvious oil residue. No doubt they had been washed, but still. Also, the carpet in the treatment room was oily and awful. Carpets don't belong in massage rooms. The slippers in the bathroom were really oily and dusgusting.  Also, I asked before I came whether the girl giving the massage was experienced with sports injuries and was told that she was. However, she was a student and had only been giving massages for 1 year. She was really sweet and I did feel she did a good job of what she was trained to do, though, and to be fair, it definitely helped, so I can't complain on that level. However, some things she said gave me a strong impression that their training could be more complete. It was surprising that she had trouble understanding that I needed a wet towel to wipe down in order to avoid getting my clothes oily.  But it's a great initiative and I hope they keep expanding.

column7: Very good experience, definitely to repeat!
column8: I visited Seeing Hands in Lalitpur yesterday. I had been sick the days before and my body was sore all over, so I thought a massage could help. The place is in a nice neighbourhood and it's quite and clean, isolated from the noise and dust of the city. Ramji gave me a great massage of 60 min, he's a skilled and sensitive masseur and also a very friendly person! I definitely recommend the experience, and I will make it a regular appointment for myself!

Today I visited Seeing Hand's Patan location for a one hour massage from Ramji. I can say without doubt that it was one of the best massage's I've ever had. It was more than a massage really. I feel like Ramji worked on deep core issues to treat the cause instead of the symptoms. I was really blown away at the quality of his work and his skill. He is highly trained and has a natural touch for figuring out structural issues. I will be going back soon for a follow up, not on his suggestion, but because I thought it was that amazing. Really top notch. Ramji is also just a good guy. The facilities are also very clean and the price is incredibly fair. I can't recommend Seeing Hands, and Ramji, enough. Check out the Patan location! It is less busy and a nice, quiet neighborhood.

column7: Best massage I've ever had - far exceeded expectations!
column8: I visited Seeing Hands on my day off after a tiring few weeks of work, having found them on tripadvisor as I was staying near by. I arrived late at the end of the day, but Ramji held on for me to arrive and the experience was wonderful. I had a 90minute sports remedial massage - the first massage I've ever had that actually felt like it was doing something seriously good to my muscles and body! Ramji was so perceptive and talented. Also really great value. Sadly it was my last day in Kathmandu, otherwise I would be a regular. Thank you Seeing Hands, hope to be back one day - Alexandra, London

column7: Great massage for loosening up a knotted back
column8: I had an excellent massage here from Ramji. I chose the Swedish massage for 90 minutes and it was great at un-knotting my back and shoulders. Ramji was careful to adjust the strength of the massage to the right level to combine power and relaxation. The place is clean and, for me, a good point is they don’t bother with the dolphin sounds or ethereal music. Instead we had an interesting chat.  Seeing Hands seems to have a nice model of formally training masseurs with proper skills and then opening up new clinics to employ them in.  The setting for the Patan clinic is peaceful on the top floor of a house set back from the road. The entrance is next to a Toyota showroom and there are some signs along the road.  It’s probably best to phone in advance to make an appointment.

Been going to Seeing Hands for a loooong time, because that is what real massages feel like rather than just rubbing oil all over you. After a stressful week or an intense trek, they just make all the pain go away. The masseurs themselves are genuinely welcoming, witty and interesting, having talked to them is a nice plus for the massages.

I've always had neck and shoulder pain, but it was worsened when I was in Nepal doing PhD research b/c of lack of exercise, poor posture while working on writing, and stress. Seeing Hands was located just down the street from where I was living. I would regularly see the female therapist Lalu who was able to help me a lot. I began to think of her as my 'back doctor!' Lulu really understood what was required to ease the tension in my back. She always checked in with me about pressure (however, I found the pressure she used for the massage to always be just right). Plus she has an excellent personality and I really enjoyed chatting with her before and after the massage.  The facilities are great. Very clean and always kept warm. The massage rooms are located on the top floor of the building up several flights of stairs, meaning accessing rooms might be difficult for some. I never called to make an appointment, so I don't know what that is like. I would often just pop by and either be seen right away, or make an appointment for later in the day when Lalu had availability. I don't remember the exact price for a 60 or 90 minute massage, but I do know the prices are very reasonable (15-25 USD range). They had a stamp card system, where your 10th massage is free. Although I tried, I was only able to fill one card before having to leave Nepal.  I'll be returning to Nepal in a few months and will definitely be back to the Lalitpur branch of Seeing Hands.

I had a very good, relaxing but strong massage at this clinic with a masseur with the odd name of 'Swashthika' (not so unusual in Hindi, I guess!). She was small but strong, and gave me just the right amount of pressure. she checked with me from time to time, to make sure it was fine with me. I will certainly be back there again! Maybe a little expensive for Kathmandu?

Even though I am not a regular massage customer, I often get one on travels, probably to feel more settled and grounded in foreign place. This time, I had a more urgent reason, a painful spot right between neck and shoulder. Lalu in her calmness made me explain where the spot is and how the rest of my body feels. She approached the spot without causing me pain and managed to make it feel really warm . The next morning I woke up and it was gone. I am still thankful for what she did and will definitly come back when travelling Nepal again.

On every monthly specil day we visit lots of religious place of kathmandu valley. Kumbeshwar temple is one of them. This temple is located 6 km south east of kathamandu at patan city. This the place where many gods and Goddess from different parts of nepal are stablised for worship. All day activities can be notice but on special day difference type of activities will be performed and many people from the valley will visting. This is the way how people of valley make their living beautiful.

We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010.This is an ancient five-story temple dedicated to Lord Shiva showcasing Pagoda style architecture which is popular in Nepal. Worth a visit when in Durbar Square, Patan.
big & impression. better to spend more time & hang around also interesting. must visit temple in Nepal

column7: Came as a Guest left as a Friend
column8: The stay was absolutly great. The Rooms are clean, the Hosts have a special way to make guests feel very welcome. The breakfast is as good as it is in a five star property. The Passion to host guest is trough out the property to see and to feel. Felt very good and made the stay very comfortable. Thank you

column7: Lack of managerial presence means zero interest by staff
column8: I attempted to book to stay for a couple of nights at this guesthouse but failed through email, online booking form and SMS to get any kind of response. However I thought I'd risk it as a starting point on arrival in Patan....and on first impression I thought it was OK, clean-ish but very basic. I saw that one room had a miniscule TV but there was just a blank screen upon turning it on. I chose a room higher up as it was cooler, and the boy working there said he'd organise a TV for me but nothing transpired after that. Having travelled from Delhi I wanted to take a shower but couldn't make the hot water work. I went all the way back down to the reception where the boy was watching a movie of some sort on his mobile phone. He came upstairs and fiddled with the taps and said 'One

This momo fast food is as infamous as a thawed industrial burger. The real taste of Nepali dishes is in the traditional local cuisines. This commercial chain did not choose the culinary pleasure to sell itself.

This is a newly opened facilities - an extension of their fast food chain based in Maharajgunj, ring road. I also visited them during their opening and later couple of times. Now they seems better organized with upstairs sitting facilities. Nice looks, ambiance, lighting, cleanliness etc. Getting popular day by day for their tastier Momo and other local short-dishes, mainly Newari style such as bada, piro aalo and its chatpate, dalle fry, mixed khaja set, chiken or veg khaja set, khukhura tareko, kothey, choila and most popularly known momos which comes with varieties such as normal steamed momo, jhol momo, fried momo, sandheko momo, open momo, c-momo etc. with four different varieties of chutney. There is also a offer, by which when you reached at buying 10 momos, you get one free - this is maintained through a coupon/card which have 10 symbols and is ticked off for every momo purchased. So far as per my knowledge they don't serves any alcoholic drinks but other soft drinks are available - may be something to considered for future (at least only upstairs). Tastes are great and I highly recommend to try it out. Now from Oct 2016, they have also opened another Bota at Kamalpokhari area. My best wishes to BOTA - simply MoMo

I’ve already written a review on Booking.com but will go into more detail here. You’ll be staying with Husband and Wife Ravi and Sushila. They are very hard working (they both work) but will make sure all your needs are attended too. You can have dinner with them in the evenings for around £3-4 per night and the Dhaal Baat is GOOD. Breakfast is good too, at around £1-2 (eggs, beans, toast etc) but they will also experiment too! I was there in December when it’s freezing and every night they filled my hot water bottle and they borrowed me a flask and filled it with hot water nightly too. I got travellers sickness from a restaurant in Thamel and Sushila made me a Nepali tonic, gave me extra toilet roll, made me dry toast and checked to make sure I was ok. Such a sweetie!

column7: Great for short or long stay
column8: This is a great place to stay in Kathmandu for either short or longer stays; you can negotiate good rates for longer stays. The area is relatively quiet and clean, plenty of low-cost local food options nearby as well as flasher restaurants. The rooms are very comfortable, competitively priced and MUCH better value for money than places around Thamel and other tourist areas. It only costs ~ $4 for taxi into tourist heart of town, and ~ 10-20cents on buses.So its worth getting away from Thamel. Black Pepper is in Patan which is much more culturally interesting than Kathmandu central anyway. The staff are very friendly and helpful. There is a generator and battery system so the daily 'load shedding' isn't too inconvenient. The guesthouse is in 'Friends Colony' which is sort of

This place has a good restaurant 'Oven' downstairs with a nice sunny terrace. The food is delicious though better to ask to make it not too "piro", see nepalese love their chili. The owners and the staff are warm and welcoming. Recommended!

Felt like home and the service is just excellent. People are very welcoming there. The food is too good. And the room interiors out there is just what reminds of Nepali tradition. Will surely visit again!

Comfortable and cosy stay in a very well renovated old traditional house. The property gives you a feeling of living back in time with all modern amenities. This unique place is a perfect location to explore as it's only a stone's throw away from Patan Durbar Square. The house is a traditional Newari house and very beautiful, the staff is friendly and helpful and the rooms clean and spacious.The restrooms are exceptionally big and good, a surprise when you look at the building. If you love to live within a traditional surrounding with local, this is going to be a great place. The hosts are great.

column7: They deserve ten stars - i feel lucky to discover this nice boutique hotel
column8: I am confused where to start, everything about this hotel is so good just words cannot explain, you have to be there to feel the hospitality they provide. The entire hotel staff are extremely well behaved, they are professionally trained and very efficient. They worked asa family and a great team. First time i stayed in a hotel for such a long time and never got a chance to complain about anything, in two visits i stayed more than 20 nights in this lovely hotel, i felt as if i was staying in home. The entire team was always present to make your stay better - the owner was always present, you will find the manager greeting you everywhere, be it at the reception or at the coffee shop or at the rooftop restaurant. They team have been trained to look everything artistic - the way

First visit and i am satisfied. The food was good. I had ordered the North Eastern set which was of decent proportions and of value for money. Although i would have preferred the chicken to be boneless and more grilled it neverthough tasted good. I totally loved the papaya salad that came along in the set. One of the best i have had in a very long time. The ambience is very modern and i just wished it would have reflected more of traditional Thailand. Nevertheless it is a good place and i would definitely visit again.
In a shopping mall admittedly, but a nice spacious airey modern restaurant. Nice red curry and the time before I had a nice green one. Easy place to go with kids.

Delicious Thai food and not very expensive. This is a new restaurant in a new modern small shopping complex in Patan, Lalitpur. This is an excellent find. Staff very attentive and very generous to us offering some free samples of food. They do 2 for one cocktails between 5-7pm and I loved the way they serve you Gin!! Highly recommend a visit here, delicious Pad Thai.

column7: High class holistic centre in a warm cosy environment!
column8: We loved Kinjala spa and the overall experience! without the noise of big and luxury hotels, but in a warm cosy environment, Kinjala provides everything you need to relax and recharge! The staff is very friendly with experience in holistic therapies, and they make sure you leave rejuvenated with a big smile! Thank you for your wonderful energy!

Spent a total of 2 days at the spa as the service and staff were brilliant. If you are looking for a clean, hygienic and professional spa experience, Kinjjala Spa is the place to visit. Took my parents here as well and they were treated royally. Ended up buying a annual package for them as was sure they would be well taken care of even in my absence.
Among many best temples in Kathmandu valley this is another.a pagoda style 17th century temple dedicated to lord vishnu !!!

Machhendranath Temple was largely destroyed by the Earthquake that hit Nepal just over a year ago. We came here to visit and see just what was left, and also to make a side trip to the nearby Karyabnayak Temple as-well. The feeling of being the only two visitors to the large open square, Villagers herding their ducks and goats through the old temple grounds actually added to the experience. I have always been a big archeology fan, so ruins excite me. These are relatively new, caused by a natural disaster, not time, although the original temples were in the 6-700 year old range. Visiting here is more of an exploration into the past. If a bunch of broken stones doesn't excite you much, I would skip this site. There's a lot of history , hundreds of small temples in the Kathmandu valley to explore. Most of the old shops and restaurants are gone, there is still one wood carver left here, turning out some beautiful HIndu and Bhuddist Statuary out of ancient pieces of wood that he imports from the Langtang region of Nepal. Worth the trip just to visit his shop.

column7: Undeerated gem of history and art
column8: Colloquially known as Uku Baha, this monastery is an incredible site to reflect on history of Buddhism, Newar society, and brass craftwork in Patan. The oldest Newari document of Kathmandu valley was found in the treasury of this monastery; the palm-leaf document dates back to early 12th century. The full-body statue of Shiva Dev, a Licchchavi king of ancient Nepal, now appears as a Rana military general providing a keen insight into how ruling classes appropriate norms and public works to serve their interest. This monastery is also a living heritage of rituals which take place in several occasions throughout the year. The monastery complex has stunning brass artwork throughout its premises. Highly recommended. Non-Nepali visitors pay NPR 30-50 for access to this monastery.
Built in the Indian style this buddhism temple is undamaged by 2015 earthquake. Not easy to find this shrine. There is a small shrine devoted to Maya Devi, the Buddha's mother.
Near to patan durbar square, this temple is another beautiful one. This is a Buddhist temple but looks like Hindu temple as it is in pagoda style with few pinnacle in its top.

this temple has been,during centuries,modified with addiction in different periods,but when you enter in the inner courtyard you still can enjoy the original old struts at your right and left sides,female figurines with less decoration and an incredible modern look. the courtyard of the temple is a show of different skills,a minestrone of styles ,stones and metal work crowded with dragons ,elephants,lizards nagas and complicated mythologycal creatures,mixed with deities and flowered branches. the total result is incredibily pleasant. a statue of a dignified noble man wearing the Rana's uniform and crown is the silent withness of all this chaos. the altar in the chapel is a masterpiece of newari art.

column7: A lovely stupa built in the style of Boudhanath.
column8: I got lost one day walking from my hotel and wound up at a lovely stupa built in the style of Boudhanath. It was in a gated park surrounded by apartment buildings and the only other people there were small boys intent on prying donations out of the donation box. I circumambulated it several times and took many photos.  I gather this is the northern Ashoka Stupa but I have no idea how I got there or how I got back to Patan Durbar Square. It doesn't show in Google maps so I can't identify it for certain. After leaving I met a few wonderful people who pointed out to me that I needed to backtrack - all the way to Durbar.

column7: A secret garden you don’t want to miss
column8: We came here with a large group of friends and brought our young toddler along. Dining at Yala is fun, relaxing, and the food doesn’t disappoint!  First off, the courtyard “garden” is the perfect setting to escape the busy and noisy streets. The thick and lush greeneries will make you forget that a cloud of dust is only a few meters away. It’s serene and peaceful.  We ordered the Newari lunch with the chicken curry. The dish came with rice, lentil soup, and a variety of veggies and pickles. Presentation is too notch and the flavors truly delivers. I can not recommend the dish enough!  To top off your experience, the service is great. The owner was very friendly and recommended a few local restaurants around the Patan area. We really appreciated it!  Attached to the restaurant is a small store that sells a variety of locally made craft goods. Everything from pashmina, pottery, and jewelry.  Definitely coming back!

Multipurpose, Yala Mandala has a great setting for dinning plus in an attached beautiful old Newari house they sell arts and crafts that are locally made. Their cheese cake was one of the best I have had made from "juju dai" a type of cream cheese made in many Newari homes. Their menu is more meaty than I would like and I hope that they create more vegetarian options. I had a simple fried rice that was very tasty especially with some added chilies.

column7: What a wonderful Hotel in a fantastic location.
column8: Arrived at this Hotel in February 2020.Where I was truly greeted by some amazing receptionist staff. This hotel is relatively new and it showed this, with its freshness, all mod cons with its exceptional staff. The manager Rajesh was most helpful and did not mind doing things a little different than others, which was helpful to me. The cleanliness of the hotel was excellent and my room was one of the best that I had ever stayed in. Its location was absolutely the world's best. You are a two minute walk from Patan, where I was given a free entrance pass to the beautiful sights of Patan, courtesy of the Traditional Stay Hotel, with my stay here. The very best goes to the staff, who assist this modern hotel to meet the comforts of this guest .... Thank you.

This was a fantastic hotel for a great price! Very close to the Golden Temple and Patan Durbur Square. Highly recommend this wonderful hotel! Clean and modern facilities and very friendly staff. You’ll love it!

column7: Peaceful and Great place to stay at resonable price
column8: I visited Panday's Paradise to make booking for my guests. I found the place to be very peaceful and very green. The place is well maintained and view from the top of the house is simply awesome. You could see a pond of the central zoo and if you look carefully you can spot a rhino as well as a deer. The place is at a great location and the pricing is simply reasonable for the place. I would strongly recommend Panday's place for the host and staff being so polite and friendly.

Stunning guest house with beautiful decor. The staff are so friendly and helpful and can’t do enough for you. Unfortunately I became unwell during my stay in Patan, and Khim, one of the staff members, was incredibly helpful and attentive, checking on me regularly and bringing me fresh bottles of water to make sure I was okay. He even arranged for a takeaway to be delivered for my partner when I was too ill to leave the room! A fantastic stay and would definitely return. And thank you again to Khim for looking after me so well!

column7: Fantastic experience as for the first time visiting Nepal!
column8: Amazing small hotel. Very charming and kept in traditional style. Friendly staff and amazing location. Very close to the square, cafes, restaurants and all necessary spots to visit. We had amazing 3 nights, feeling welcomed and comfortable.

column7: Charming place, comfortable room, good service
column8: A good place to stay in Patan. The Durbar Square is just a couple of meters away and there a lot of nice shops around. The hotel is charming and the staff were friendly, attentive and nice. They attended to our requests quickly, helped us with directions and offered tips on how to make our trips in Kathmandu better.

This small clean hotel could do with a lick of paint but it is clean comfortable with helpful staff. Don't stay out too late the main gate was locked by 23.30hrs. The food is good but it can be an interesting interpretation of European/American classics.

column7: Once again at the Hotel Clarion in Lalitpur, Nepal
column8: The hotel staff is awesome! They make my time in Nepal all the more excellent as they are helpful at all times with any of my requests. The rooms are clean and quaint with new lace curtains added since my last stay. I eat many of my meals at the Hotel Clarion with enjoyment. The location is ideal for my reasons to be here in Nepal. I will mention I have been staying at this hotel for over 16 years. I simply like the owner Binay with his fine integrity and his finely selected staff. I will mention the pricing is competitive and reasonable too. I suggest the Hotel Clarion with ease!

After a thorough 3-month search through hundreds of hotels/guest houses in the Kathmandu area to host very special adoption family reunion, we finally landed on Summerhill House in Lalitpur. I cannot say enough great things about this peaceful get-away in the heart of such a busy city! Beginning with the warm and wonderful owners of these beautiful Newari style inns, it only gets better with the excellent service, ideal location, added services (touring and transportation as needed) and lovely rooms - including common space for hanging out and relaxing. And, let's not forget the delicious Nepali cooking, the brand new yoga studio and a guarded, gated entrance! It was the perfect place for us, and for anyone looking for a traditional, yet modern, Nepali experience. I highly

column7: A lovely home away from home
column8: It is a small basic lodging. But with friendly staff who go out of thier way to make you feel at home. Lodging comes with a cooked breakfast! Rooms are basic but clean. Would highly recommend it. There are various restaurants and cafes all within walking distance. Most convenient.

Yala Guesthouse has the best location - right at the Durbar square. From your window you see all the pagodas and the palace. The price for the room (initially 1500NRP) is too high for the simple room you get. So you need to negotiate hard! The room was very dusty. The restaurant doesn't function. Unfortunately Yala doesn't use all the potential it could have. For this price you can get nicer accommodation elsewhere.

column7: We made it thru the rain
column8: 10 Aug 2015 and it was raining but we made it thru to this resto, we ordered 3 main course and I ordered chicken on the nest, it was great taste but to me as an Indonesian, I just need chilli sauce to make it more great. Nice ambience and atmosphere although it was raining.

column7: Charm in Patan with Great Shopping Next Door
column8: Right next to a huge Bhatbhatteni department store, but tucked away in a courtyard is The Embers, a restaurant often frequented by ex-pats working for UN or other agencies, as well as locals. The courtyard al fresco setting is quite nice and tables are not crowded together, making dinner conversation possible. Upstairs is additional seating, and small private rooms if you want to hold a meeting. Decor is simple, modern and clean. There are also a few upscale stores as you walk in, so you can eat and shop at the same time!  Food is tasty and there is a good selection of continental, Nepali and Chinese fare. I had the Crepes Florentine, and they were yummy, not smothered with sauce and prettily served on the plate with some lettuce in a glass cup. Service was courteous and very prompt. Arjun Raj Giri, the GM, is very experienced, and has worked in some of the top hotels in the country.  This is a lovely escape from the rush of Kathmandu!

Tanani Newa is such a beautiful home! I have lived here for over a month and have felt so comfortable the whole time. They have made a lot of effort to prepare a very welcoming and warm environment. They do not treat it as only a business but as it is their home, they make great effort to treat you as their welcomed guests. They also have genuine concern for your well-being and safety. If you need ideas of places to visit or if you need any help, they have good knowledge of the area and have many connection as their family history goes back in this area for a long time. This is the best option anywhere in the area if you need a place to stay!

Comfortable,clean,well furnushing,made us feel like a home,warm welcoming. Thanks to Dr.Bhimlal Tamang for suggesting me such a wonderful place including Milan bhai for ur kindness and good service.Love to visit again.🙂

This hotel is great! My husband and I stayed here for a night, and we really enjoyed the view of Patan Durbar Square from our room and the mountain views from the rooftop terrace. The hotel is built in a traditional Newari style with a modern twist (much of the decor is authentic Newari art). The rooms are a great size. The bathrooms are super clean and very nice. There were lots of amenities, like toothbrushes, toiletries, and a hair dryer in the bathroom. The bed was very comfortable. The WiFi was excellent for Nepal. There were only two downsides. The water bottle in the room was not sealed, so we didn’t drink it. Second, the square was kind of loud early in the morning (around 5 AM), but this could have been because of the holidays. Regardless of the two downsides, we

column7: Simply Superb! Magical location, excellent accommodation.
column8: This is the perfect place to stay in Kathmandu for those interested in the city's astonishing art, architecture, culture and history. I am already looking forward to staying here next time I visit Kathmandu (this was a work-related trip). Highlights are the location, the charming staff and the 'hidden Patan' walking tour that the most welcoming and enthusiastic proprietor very kindly took us on. Rooms are spacious, comfortable, well-decorated, very clean, with amenities. Bathroom is modern, bright, wet-room style. The views from the windows and top-floor terrace are superlative - you are practically in the temples. Highest recommendations for Heraya La:Ku

column7: A good place for the getaway
column8: You will find the location on the way to Godavari Park. Being away from the hustle and bustle of city it's just what you need for a getaway. The location is just on the road and people might feel you'll be disturbed but it is actually quiet and feel like you want. Peace. There is a swimming pool as well which was clean. For child and non swimmers like me and for swimmers the pool is separated so easily one can enjoy the swimming. Foods are good. The Manager of hotel was really good enough and cooperative to manage our requests. Staffs were all welcoming and I was impressed with the hospitality provided by the hotel. We took one night stay package on BB Basis. The rooms are nice as well. I just wished that the Breakfast had more varieties. Overall it was a pleasant stay for us.

I stayed one month in this very nice place, where Leela and her family made their best to make me feel at home. I would definitely go back there. I also appreciated very much staying far from tourist places such as Thamel. A peaceful and pleasant place to stay in Kathmandu. Electricity 24 hours a day, and even internet, although this was not always the fastest connection. Nice view from the balconies and the roof !

Bottom line up front? Stay here. Honestly struggling to put together words that describe how fantastic this place is. Heartwarming? Generous? Genuine. The hospitality of the staff here is amazing, and I was truly sad to have to leave. The building is brand new, clean and stylishly designed. Locally owned, which I LOVE. Very spacious beds and well designed and secure storage areas. Good food, great coffee (rare in KTM!), and lots of really comfortable little areas to settle into. Had the best yoga instruction of my entire life when they organised a few classes here. There always seems to be an event happening, so it's actually a really great blend of a relaxed chill atmosphere, with enough social vibe to make sure you have somewhere to go and feel included and connected if

The rooms were very comfortable, clean and nice. The staffs were amazing and very friendly. They also were able to recommend places to get any type of meal that we needed as well. They went over and beyond to help make our stay enjoyable. I highly recommend this place for anyone visiting here.

It is a tiny little place with a small team. Very cosy. Traditional newari style house. They also have a cafe and serve breakfast, coffee and cakes. Try their cakes and handmade chocolates. Delicious. They don't have their own parking so you might have to talk to the staff to find a parking near by if you have your own vehicles. Value for money.

I stayed at the full serviced apartment. It is a three storied apartment typical of local Newari style. Cooked most days so I could save up some money. On days that I wasn't feeling like cooking, I ordered from the hotel. They serve amazing breakfast and cakes. The staff are very friendly, so even though i stayed there for long, they made me feel like home. Convenient location is an added value and so is easy to navigate for people who are new to the city.

column7: Wonderful stay at the heart of Patan Durbar Square
column8: Pahan Chhen offered us a wonderful stay at the heart of the quaint historical district of Patan Durbar Square. The staff was very professional, welcoming and helpful. The room was clean, comfortable and well equipped with flat screen, hot water, Italian style shower and balcony. The hotel is at the heart of durbar square and near several pleasant shops and cages. The dinner on the rooftop offered us an amazing view over monuments we enjoyed from the bottom during day time. The breakfast at the ground floor was in a pleasant traditional interior design atmosphere.

column7: The worst meal I have ever had in a restaurant
column8: I went to Third World Restaurant for a lunch while visiting Durbar Square. The nice view of Durbar Square was the only good thing about it and you can get that from other nearby restaurants. I had Newari set meal which was inedible at best and the only reason why it didn't make me sick was that I couldn't finish it. The soup was sour like it has gone bad. From the main course I ate white beans which were very plain, potatoes which had no taste and were cold and pancake which was very crumbly and dry. I couldn't stomach the rest of the food. I attempted to eat small round black beans but almost broke my teeth. Even though I was the only customer, it took them ages to come and clean my table. I ended up giving up on waiting and went to pay my bill at their reception area.

We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010.This Hindu temple dedicated to both Lord Vishnu and Lord Shiva is a tall three storey pagoda style architecture and is located opposite the entrance to Patan Durbar Square museum. We saw it from outside.

column7: great quality, worthy to check out
column8: We were touring Patan Dubai Square and was led to this little store. The owner did a demonstration, explaining the made, the difference in size, and balancing your chakras using these handmade singing bowl. I supposed they do a sound bowl therapy if u asked.  It may be seems abit pricey, but I feel that at least it gives u some peace of mind you are sold the real deal than other touristy places outside. He was patient to give us some quick crash course on how to use the bowl to its fullest potential! Looking forward to explore the one we picked.

Om handicrafts is different than other places that sell singing bowls. All of their bowls are handcrafted with different precious metals. Their hospitality is the best. They don't just sell their bowls, but also provide a demonstration of a short therapy session, that will resonate with your soul. Highly recommended!

This fair trade store has an amazing selection of scarves and jewelry but the real stars are the top quality singing bowls. We've purchased several bowls that are far superior to the ones on the street. The demonstration of the singing bowls is interesting and educational.
Purchased a "Full Moon" bowl after an interesting demonstration. Staff was helpful in choosing the right bowl.

We stayed in the apartments above Om Handicrafts and although we were under the impression that all the rooms were on the same floor whereas they were actually on three separate levels the place was lovely. It was a family run business who were very friendly. The rooms were clean and comfortable and felt very safe. And when there were strikes on the day of our departure when we talked about it beforehand they offered if we couldn't find anything ourselves (which was our intention) they would help us getting safe transport to the airport by finding us a car with green plates. Well recommended.

We visited this store with a group and I was immediately impressed with the competency of their demonstration of the products. The bowls themselves were of excellent quality and we purchased two which were shipped by UPS and these arrived at our home on the day that we returned as requested. Shipping was notified with a tracking number by email. The bowls were well wrapped and cushioned and in a proper marine ply box to protect them. This is not a cheap shop but one gets value for money and I would recommend them without reservation. Please note duty will be payable on receipt in the UK and presumably elsewhere in the EU. They took credit cards.

Staying at Om's Apartments (which is just above Om Handicrafts) was an absolute pleasure. It was beautifully appointed, clean, comfortable, warm and safe. Also it is situated in a very beautiful part of Kathmandu. Our family of 4 (2 adults and 2 children age 10 and 6) were most perfectly accommodated in 2 separate apartments. Though we ate out a lot, there is a clean and well equipped kitchen upstairs. The staff are both warm and professional. My children loved going downstairs to Om's Handicrafts to see their exquisite singing bowls and to chat to them and to listen to the magnificent sounds. Manoj, Abhi and Raaz were always available to answer questions and to help us. By the end of our stay I was very sad to leave such special people and a place that housed us so well. My only regret is not buying more singing bowls. They are truly therapeutic and make for wonderful gifts also.

Run by very welcoming, friendly and helpful people with also a sense for social responsibility. They are happy to explain more about the process of the production, origin, history, etc. of their handicrafts as well as they also know how to use their Healing Bowls. They give a nice demonstration about how to use the Healing Bowls and are very patient and helpful if you are interested and trying to find your personal bowl. I haven't been to one of the apartments. But after having seen the store, I guess they must be very nice and for sure clean.

column7: One of the Three Durbars of Kathmandu
column8: The Pathan Durbar Square houses the Palace of Pathan. It was built in the 17th Century. The palace temple is used to make sacrifices. On either side of the temple door was golden statues of the 2 river goddesses of the rivers that flow there. It is definately worth a visit.

Amazing roof top terrasse. Warming welcome in this traditional building. Authentic wooden windows in newari style. Very nice accomadation. Close to Durbar Square. We were a group visiting Patan and we really enjoyed sleeping here. We felt at home thanks also to the host.

Goathchen is a lovely little 300-year old guest house tucked away in a quiet alley literally just around the corner from Patan Durbar square. The rooms are clean and charming with warm running water. Bed was comfortable with spring mattress and synthetic pillows. The owner and his wife are very generous and kind; they looked after us and offered delicious breakfast (local yoghurt, eggs, fresh fruit and coffee/tea) in the lush courtyard. They even took the time and celebrated my birthday with a traditional Newari ceremony with offerings and flowers. So sweet! If you are looking for an authentic home stay experience I would definitely recommend Goathchen.

column7: Peace and Tranquility in the bustling and chaotic city of Kathmandu!
column8: We stay in this hotel every time we are in Kathmandu because it feels like a home away from home. The suites with bedrooms, kitchen and living room have complete privacy from next door neighbor, and perfect for short or long term stay at a very reasonable price in the city. It is in the heart of a hectic and bustling city, and yet, you feel safe, relaxed and peaceful once inside the hotel. The location is excellent; you can either walk or take a short cab ride to Patan Durbar Square and other city attractions in Kathmandu; shopping and restaurants are at walking distances. Everything in the hotel looks and feels fresh and new, staffs are very hospitable and don't hesitate to go extra mile to help make your stay wonderful. Rooftop has breathtaking 360 deg view of entire Kathmandu

I stayed here for 3 weeks while freelancing for a INGO in the area - many INGOs and NGOs operate out of Lalitpur. The location at the corner of Patan Durbar Square could not be better, endless culture and atmosphere, easy access to a range of food options including the excellent Swotha Cafe, an extensively easy place to direct a taxi to from anywhere in the KTM valley, and of course also conveniently located for the work I was there to do. The solar shower was excellently hot, the small apartment I was in (1 large room) was comfortable, modern, and also exceptionally clean. The wifi was strong however did require some troubleshooting - frankly as it does nearly everywhere in Kathmandu - and any connectivity issue was also promptly addressed. A separate entrance allowed me to

column7: Service with heart and a smile
column8: If you want to experience the heart and love of the people of Nepal and give into their economy then go visit Bikram and Preeti. They have the biggest of hearts to make you welcome and serve you as their guest, always going above and beyond to make your stay as comfortable as possible. The accommodation is comfortable and once you get your bearings, it's a fine place away from the hectic and loud places such as Thamel. Please remember that many nations have set up in Nepal and run their own guest houses making it very difficult for the locals to compete. Champion the local beautiful people and support their business.

Cora Nepal is a unique place. In Kathmandu you will rarley find a lot of hoses in a safe neighbourhood with such a heartful and light-flooded interior design, lovely decorations, friendly and flexible hosts who make sure that you feel welcome and comfortable throughout your stay, a lovely Didi who takes care of the rooms every single day, a Roof terrace to enjoy the mild evenings, a green garden filled with fresh vegetables and herbs and delicious and fresh breakfast facilities for the perfect start into the day. From the start I felt like home at Cora Nepal and was able to relax from the hustles of the city. The area of Sanepa is known for the delicious restaurants and cafés in walking distance. Great Yoga and Fitness studios are close by. Definitely my favorite place to stay

I would absolutely recommend staying with Cora - it was such a treat to stay here. As soon as I arrived to the guesthouse I was welcomed by Shei with open arms and she made me feel comfortable and at ease right away. As a solo traveller on a long term stay this was much needed, and I was even so lucky to have other long term "roommates" while I was here - which made me feel even more at home! The house is absolutely beautiful and you can sense the love and attention to detail that has been put into this project. The fresh fruits and eggs from the garden make a delicious breakfast along with local coffee, which you can either enjoy in the cosy kitchen or on the rooftop terrace (which on most days have an amazing view - you might even be able to see one of the Himalaya peaks while

I have to pit this here as 'Pin Bahal Pokhari isn't mentioned on Trip Advisor. If you make it to this Ganesh shrine then you are 5 minutes away from the above mentioned pond/lake. Mentioned in the Lonely Planet this place is worth checking out. The pond is the size of a soccer pitch do you'll know when you find it. With your back to the Ganesh temple, don't walk towards the Patan Gate, don't walk back towards the Durbar sq. Take the other road south west, and you'll be there in under 5 minutes.

First of all the lack of a decent parking space and accessibility to the parking space was discouraging. Nevertheless, we expected the meals to cover for the disappointment we encountered. I had ordered a Pepper Steak(tenderloin steak with Redwine cream sauce accompanied with fries and...More

Ohhh dear, momo is looked like momocha. Not atypical Dhajeeling or Tebatian style. It was typical Kathmandu style momocha. I was really disappointed with staffs. No confident and knowledge about menu. I asked for chatney for momocha, never arrived.

Cafe Antardristi is a cozy place with friendly staffs and also very close to my office . I make sure I drink at least one cup of organic coffee each day here as the contribution I make collectively goes to a great cause that this...More

This nice place serves very good coffees and waffles. Besides that they serve burgers and pasta. Good thing of the café is that the profit they make is used to support awareness classes on trafficking and abuse of girls.

Well, not really, but GG Machaan bills itself as “Feeling Jungle in the City”.  My wife and I have lived in Kathmandu for a little over a year now and when I decided to take off a recent Friday to make a long weekend, I was certain the October weather would be fine. I was wrong. The monsoon, that a few days before seemed to have dissipated, was back. A steady rain settled in making our planned excursion to the Kopan Monastery problematic. When the veil of rain still hadn’t lifted by 11:30 Saturday morning, we scrubbed our plans and headed to lunch.  We visited GG Machaan several months ago and I remembered it as having a pleasant, covered outdoor terrace which made it a good candidate for lunch on a rainy day. We arrived at 12:15 after a short drive and were immediately seated. My memory was correct. The two level outdoor terrace is bamboo covered and sports photos of Nepali royalty hunting for big game in times long past. The menu contains predominantly Nepali snacks but also a mix of western fare and Indian food.  After a brief perusal of the menu, we settled on Perale mushrooms (oyster mushrooms battered w/Benal gram flower, green chili, garlic) and the GG fried Basa fish. The waiter capably took our order and read everything back to make sure he had it correct. While we waited for our order to arrive, I tapped my foot to cover versions of popular tunes played in the background. After a reasonable wait, the mushrooms arrived. What was immediately noticeable to us was that the chef had clearly considered the presentation of this simple dish. In most restaurants around town, food is unceremoniously dumped on the plate. Here, the main dish was carefully plated and garnished with carved vegetables. Nice! The taste was as good as the presentation.  No sooner had we polished off the mushrooms than the fish arrived. The presentation of golden-fried chunks of Basa fish equaled that of the now disappeared mushrooms. The Basa fish soon suffered the same fate. As we lingered on the quiet terrace enjoying a rainy afternoon it was clear to us that we had chosen wisely.  While GG Machaan is no jungle, it is a place for good food, well presented in comfortable surroundings.

GG machaan is probably the place that could help to make you feel you are in jungle yes there is no live tiger no live rhino and elephant but still you can feel that you are in jungle in the city with mouth watering food with great music.

New and exciting environment which is designed with a unique style and decorum, accompanied by great live music on Wednesday and Friday. Complimentary starter by the Chef, good portion and great service.

column7: Good bistro and cafe food with good drink selection.
column8: Nice casual garden where you can create a canvas masterpiece at House of Pallettes over lunch. Their vegetarian menu can have more variety though.

Situated in a spacious yard this modern cafe serves you delicious and elegantly presented meals and drinks. Staff is helpful and friendly and here is room for fiends and family and your car. In the years you also find the art studio House of Palettes and a tattoo parlour among other.

column7: Quint Guesthouse in the middle of Patan Durbar
column8: A newly renovated, small and warm guesthouse just at the back alley of Patan Durbar square. It has all the facilities that your need, A Western style bathroom, with water heater ( not solar) on each floor, there two double room per floor. Clean and comfortable room and bed, one of the best we had in Nepal. The guest house is hard to find as there is no signage and signboard, but once you locate it you will appreciate it location, it just a alley away from the main square, but it quieter than those guesthouse facing the square. You can just sit near the windows of the room and soak in the slow lifestyle of nepal. the only set back is the water heater is electrical, given the erratic electric supply of nepal, you have to time your shower or you might have to take a cold shower

The foods I've tried were all tasty! The ice cream is AMAZING, especially the strawberry and matcha flavor - I can see they use really good ingredients and make everything from scratch. The staff are kind and the atmosphere is relaxing. Highly recommended!!
I went there with my friends for lunch. We tried the nepali style appetizer chicken chilly and paneer pakauda. Price was reasonable so was the food average. Service is ok

column7: Excellent food and an AWESOME atmosphere!
column8: When you find Station BBQ (worth doing, I promise) you walk thru the gates into a courtyard filled with pommelo fruit trees, soothing music alla Hotel Costes and a nice grouping of inviting tables and comfortable sofas. The entire design made me feel like I...More

column7: The best BBQ ive ever had!!
column8: You can make your own bbq right on top of your table. Outside seating is very cozy and comfortable good for couple or a group. They have a nice seating inside with a nice bar and have a private rooms for corporate or family gathering. They have mouthwatering multi cuisine bbq and ala carte menu plus a wide selection of wines and spirits. Ive really enjoyed the grilled veggies with organic salad, bread rolls and homemade sauces of bbq, mint, chili and mustard. If you are too lazy to grill your own bbq the chef will do it for you in their glass partitioned see through kitchen where you can be assured of good hygiene and sanitation. Price and service are fantastic. Had a wonderful dining experience. Would visit again next time.

I am an occasional visitor to this place. I normally go there when I feel like plenty of authentic Nepali food. I recommend people to try Nepali Rice set or Dhido set with chicken or mutton. You will love the ambience and the place has...More
Come here for terrific food and make some good friends. This is unlike any other restaurant, with places for young children to play and a trampoline. And did I mention how good the food is???

Its a little outside of the city so you'll need to have some time to spare for meal there. Food takes a little time but is perfectly cooked and well served. Some delicacies have great german taste and style obviously since owner Mr. Walter is...More

column7: Great spot for food and culture in Patan
column8: Had some amazing Newari food and excellent conversation with Ashmina and Basanta. Very comfortable atmosphere- reminds me of hanging out in my dad's ceramics studio.
A great multi cultural meeting place with authentic Nepalese food as well as pizza. Visiting artists, open mike nights and movies all create a lot of fun and a mix of populations.
Very good ambience and location. Spacious and cosy. Veg momos and mmuchroom chilly was very delicious to recommend. Sitting with bunch of friends and families makes feel like home here.

column7: Food is just "meh". Once had amazing cheesecake which is no longer on menu
column8: The best thing about this place used to be the espresso cheesecake, which seems to have disappeared from the menu. The food is ok- nothing special, but small portions for the price. The ambiance is nice and cozy, western style joint. The sandwiches are decent....More

column7: Best Sliders and cocktails in Kathmandu
column8: Great atmosphere and love the decoration. Also great food. I had a sliders and also a passionfruit mojito with was incredible. Also the staff are very friendly and make you feel welcome.

Food with that extra dash of love is what Café Aamu promises its visitors and the very first thing they realize when visiting the café is how well it delivers its promise. Delicious cuisine that reminds you of homemade food, love and warmth of the...More

This place sticks out like a diamond in the rough! I was staying nearby before my trip to Everest Base Camp. The food in Kathmandu is fantastic, but after some time it's always a nice site to see a super modern clean place that reminds...More

column7: One of my shelters in Boudha
column8: Whenever I go to Nepal and make my usual rounds of Stupa in Boudha I stop here to enjoy their very good apple pie or brownies.. The place is nice, wifi works (when power is available!!!). I feel like home..

It is one of the best place in Kathmandu if you are passionate about sports. Big are and good projection of English Premier League made this bar more attractive. Few bottles of beer and cocktail rolls will make your time more passionate. I find the...More

Really enjoyed this cafe, great coffee, food and service. Closest to feeling you are in Europe with this cafe with attention to detail from the owners and the staff. Really good coffee especially the layered lattes so very impressive, go every time in Kathmandu

column7: Fun to explore multi level store
column8: Heard about this store and fair market mission. Stopped in alone to browse; just set up for Christmas ! Walked out spending $23 American. Made me think twice because that's more than alot of people make a day here. .. Lovely things, made in country, reasonably priced. Where else can you get a yeti ornament for your tree?

A great shop to make your new house in Kathmandu look like home. Open 7 days a week, full of beautiful interior pieces: lamps, crockery, linen, bed covers, copper...check it our. Small parking space at the side.
Visited After one of my friend shared its services. I finally found a place to make my pain stress go vain

Beautiful spa. So clean and relaxing. Besides being located in a gorgeous property, Chaitanya offers a pleasant ambiance. This place is awesome! They really understand and make sure that you are pampered and made to feel that you are the MOST important person there. The staff has exceeded our expectations in every interaction and went extra mile to deliver a memorable experience. I feel rejuvenated and recharged. Thank you, Chaitanya. Definitely recommending to my friends!

Expert was well aware of the job.. and they were not in hurry to completed the spa.. touched each and every important points of body to make you relaxed and rejuvenated..  I strongly recommend everyone to have this experience once u r in kathmandu.

I went to Chaitanya as recommended by my Guest House. This review is about a massage as I did not participate in the spa. The building was acceptable but nothing special. The staff was welcoming and the massage therapist was good. The deep tissue massage was not as revitalizing as I expected, more of a swedish massage. Perhaps that is their specialty.  The biggest draw back was the ambience, or lack there of. People were yelling and the spa was expanding right next to my room. The hammer jack and noise was disturbing. Moreover, twice someone entered my room. I don't like people coming in and out.  While the massage was okay, I will not be returning. I found the massage at the Seeing Hands Clinic to be far better in all areas.

Basecamp has been a place where it has people from all ages to all profession hanging out. It is a outdoorsy venue with a simple bar and you can order food from restaurants around the area. Its a great hangout places for all types of artists. People here make new friends, help new people in town with the collect what to do list in Nepal and make some amazing memories!

The MountainChild Guest House is an oasis. The main rooms and guest rooms are beautifully decorated and the staff’s excellent hospitality create a warm and inviting home away from home. The easy access to many great restaurants is an added bonus! This guest house will be my first choice when visiting Kathmandu again in the future!

Bhatbhateni reminds me of the Walmart stores in the US, with about as little charm, though it's a good place to get stuff without running all over the city. This is one store of a chain and they are definitely the largest stores I've seen in Nepal. There's a big supermarket on the ground floor. Other floors have clothing, luggage, electronics, furniture, etc. Prices are on the low side.

This one of the best places in Kathmandu (Patan). Unpretentious but excellent food and very nice garden to sit outside(also shaded places). They do not make much publicity and you have to look (corner of Patan Dokha and Krishna Galli). I have eaten here several...More

Loved the stay here and came back several times. Clean quiet great location and an amazing host who really goes out of his way to help. It's very close to durbar square and the rooms are quite modern with fine decor. Our host and the extra services he provided made my trip exceptional.

column7: Best place for work and nice fresh food
column8: Suburb is a clean, modern Guesthouse with big bedrooms and a very good restaurant. The breakfast is fresh and there are a lot of things to choose from. I used this place to work and the WiFi is very good everywhere, even in the garden - what is my favorite place. Also for lunch and diner Suburb is my favorite. The service is perfect and the guy's can tell you many things about the food and the menu. I think Suburb is a special place to stay because of the location, it's unique, clean and very charming.

Do not go there if you are looking for peace and quiet: it is a very noisy neighbourhood, and there is no way to sleep in the morning, you have to wake up with the community. Lots of works around, hammers and loud noise in the morning... The bed is comfortable though, and the whole style of the building is nice. The staff is warm and helpful. The situation is a plus, since you're close to everything (temples all around). I wouldn't recommend the breakfast too much : juice is "Real" (sugar and colouring) and the jam is "Druk" (the worst jam of Asia). Too bad they don't serve a little quality products, it would definitely raise the bar globally...

column7: Excellent place. It is just around 500 meters to Patan Durbar Square.
column8: Excellent place. Traditional house, clean rooms and bathrooms. Have access to common sitting place and marvelous views of mountains and hills. If you are sitting long term then have few studio apartments with kitchen utensils, refrigerator and micro-oven. Staffs are helpful and informative. Beds are comfortable have sitting area as well. Hot pot in the room with coffee and sugar is best as you can make your own coffee. Highly recommended for family and groups.

This Bungamati home-stay is community based best home stay for traditional and modern culture learner. It is better to stay and visit all around Bungamati old village which is full of traditional culture, wooden art skill and traditional and modern mix knowledge to click beautiful scenes. The capital city Kathmandu of Nepal is near Bungamati about 10 KM. Thank.

I' ve been here for a week in 2014. Lovely place, lovely people, clean rooms and you're own bathroom. A perfect stay if you want to relax from the hectic of Kathmandu. Or want to make daytrips in the valley. The owners will help you with everything and speak very good english. A perfect place!!!! Noëlle

column7: Real Sherpa food and much more!
column8: Sherpa specialities like thukpa, shakpa, and rigikur highlight the menu, but they make the best onion rings I have ever had and a creamy shrimp and rice dish to die for. Momos, the Tibetan dumplings that are ubiquitous in Nepal, are argued about regularly, but...More

It was a great holiday for me. Everything was well planned and managed. Hotels was excellent and guide/transport was also excellent. the service we got was above expectations. One of the best holiday !!!

Did the Annapurna Circuit Trek with THT back in October 2018. Upon arrival & during the trek, we were so well taken care of that the numerous reviews we read online about trekking in Nepal exceeded our expectations. The guides were knowledgeable, very patient, friendly & always…

Everything was fantastic! the tour guide Shree is really helpful, knowledgeable and anxious to make your trip to Nepal unique and wonderful. I really wanted to see the rural areas of Nepal and told him that i am interested to see some schools because of my studies, he organized…

Khempalung Adventure has surpassed my expectations of what it means to be trekking in the Himalayas. From the time I got in touch with Mr Ashim Pradhan and Dawa Sherpa. They guided me and my friend and gave all possible end to end services to make my trip a success. Many thanks…

This two month stay in Nepal was just unforgettable...First of all i have to thank Chin and his whole family for their unbelievable hospitality and kindness. Living with them they made me feel like a family member. When i came back to their house after my trips somehow i always…

I had an amazing time in nepal! First of all I had the opportunity to teach english in a women school in kathmandu and visit some projects in the mountains. It was a georgeos experience. And the second thing is that we could make a lot of tours with ganesh and chin :) Amazing…
